B00005JODA|3.0|3.5 /5 <br /> <br />The theatre was packed tonight, a Wednesday night, for what looked like a film that promised relief from the stream of duds and shallow movies as of late. <br /> <br />Ralf Fiennes plays Brit diplomat, Justin Quayle, on location in Kenya. His wife, 24 year-old Tessa (34 year-old Rachel Weisz) , tags along with handsome Dr. Arnold Bluhm as he visits the villages, dishing out medical aid. Tessa is a committed social activist, critical of conglomerates who hand out free medicine, etc., and pieces together her observations with the Dr. to come up with a conspiracy theory that she submits to a respected higher up in the British High Commission. Of course, big trouble later ensues. <br /> <br />Shot with many flash backs, the film is about Justin's one-man investigation of his wife's murder and the greedy players in the busines and political world who promise to profit enormously from the shady pharmaceutical industry's practices. <br /> <br />Some of camera work was disorienteering, as it is shot with a shaky hand-held camera. Some of the footage seems pointless. What's the point of having the scene with the bandits raiding the remote village? It's a bit disturbing to see the fleeing villagers being chased, shot or captured, while the huts burn to the ground. With a couple of scenes, you really get a sense of how little life is regarded over there as compared to the first world. <br /> <br />The main problem with this film is that it felt so unfocused. It's too long and drawn out. It's not a clear, succinct thriller. The sound in some of the room scenes is full of echoes. If you thought this was going to be anything like The English Patient, which also starred Ralf Fiennes, you will be surprised. The romance is played up but this is not a romance film. Fiennes, who is usually reserved in his roles, is surprisingly smiley with some boyish charm. Overall, the acting was quite solid.
B0009UC7H0|4.0|I have not yet read any of Clive Cussler's novels, but given how vehemently his fans are insisting that his books are so much better than this movie I will have to check them out because this movie is pretty good (and Cussler signed off on the script and the casting, which certainly undercuts complaints about the same).  Of course, any movie that begins with a Civil War ironclad going down a river with guns blazing is going to appeal to me (although my wife thought I have started playing the wrong movie).  Then again, it was really upsetting at the film's climax to see the C.S.S. Texas getting shot up.  Yes, I know it is just a film, but the thought of finding such a Civil War artifact intact only to have it immediately start getting shot up momentarily took me back to the real world, which is a mistake because realism is not the name of the game here.<br /><br />\\"Sahara\\" begins at the end of the Civil War, as the Confederate ironclad Texas escapes from a burning Richmond carrying the gold supply of the Confederacy.  It disappears into history, where the lost ship becomes the latest obsession of Dirk Pitt (Matthew McConaughey), who believes the Texas crossed the Atlantic and ended up somewhere in Africa (do not ask \\"how,\\" because an explanation is not forthcoming and you know from the title of the film that Dirk is right on this score).  Dirk is partnered with Al Giordino (Steve Zahn), and if you pay attention to the title sequence you get a visual tour of their career resumes.  Technically the boys work for Admiral (Ret.) Jim Sandecker (William H. Macy), who has a hard time reining them in once Dirk finds another clue about the Texas.<br /><br />Meanwhile, Dr. Eva Rojas (Penelope Cruz) of the World Health Organization has arrived in Africa with a team to find the source of a dangerous plague that has been spreading across the region.  However, there is another problem in that Rojas is getting too close to the truth, which puts here in danger from the local dictator, General Kazim (Lennie James), and his partner, smarmy French rich guy, Yves Massarde (Lambert Wilson).  Dirk becomes involved in this because he is making a habit of rescuing Eva, and because he is looking for the legendary ironclad in the same part of the continent.  Al is along for the ride, as if Rudi Gunn (Rainn Wilson) for part of the way.<br /><br />These narrative threads are used to connect the action sequences that are the main set pieces of this 2005 film from director Breck Eisner (\\"Thoughtcrimes\\").  The best of these is the speedboat one, involving the \\"Panama,\\" which comes relatively early in the film.  I want to ask, \\"Whatever happened to saving the best for last?\\" in a film like this, but it is not like they did that in \\"Raiders of the Lost Arc,\\" so why should that happen here?  Granted, \\"Sahara\\" is not as much fun as that classic film romp, but it was certainly more enjoyable than \\"National Treasure,\\" probably because it is not as burdened by American history and national landmarks as that one (and McConaughey and Zahn both look buff enough to pull this stuff off in the world of movie reality).<br /><br />Besides, I like a film where the chemistry between the two guys is better than the chemistry between the hero and the heroine, mainly because if this film is the start of a Dirk Pitt franchise, you know Al will be back but you have to expect a different female lead in each subsequent film.  I especially liked Sandecker's third demand at the end of the film and to tell the truth, knowing nothing about the original novels, I would much rather see the team in action than Dirk teaming up with somebody new in each film.  For me the end result is that \\"Sahara\\" is an enjoyable action romp of the brainless variety.  But if you want more, then look elsewhere.ctator, General Kazim (Lennie James), and his partner, smarmy French rich guy, Yves Massarde (Lambert Wilson). B00003CXC7|5.0|Jimmy Stewart is a photojournalist confined to a wheelchair in his apartment with a broken leg. He spends most of his time gazing out the window at his neighbors, until one day he sees something that looks like a murder taking place. Grace Kelly plays his lover; she wants to marry him, but he thinks her pampered life makes her unsuitable for the rough life he leads. She, of course, leads the way in the dangerous murder probe they set out upon. It's to Hitchcock's credit that he had Kelly believe Stewart's story almost from the start, so we don't have to endure his trying to convince her it's true. (It also allows the picture to focus on its single point: she's no mamby-pamby and can do anything Stewart can.) The early going is rather slow - only the snappy dialogue saves it, though the suspense builds nicely near the end. Thelma Ritter is very good as Stewart's nurse - she has most of the wisecracking lines. The camera never leaves the apartment or the courtyard: Hitchcock loved the single setting idea during this time (see also ROPE AND LIFEBOAT). Definitely worth a watch.

B00005LB50|3.0|Two years. Three albums. A four-disc retrospective. It wouldn't seem possible to get a more comprehensive treatment of a band's career than that promised by Buffalo Springfield's unimaginitively titled BOX SET. But in fact the producers of this gorgeously packaged, extensively annotated and beautifully remastered misfire have achieved the impossible by crafting an anthology at once bloated and incomplete.<br />  Far more legendary as the incubator of the careers of Stephen Stills, Neil Young and Richie Furay than for its own output - which included exactly one hit (\\"For What It's Worth\\") and a lot of highly influential but woefully underappreciated material besides - Buffalo Springfield could and should have had the mother of all box sets, one containing every note the band ever released as well as plenty of alternates, outtakes and demos. Instead, BOX SET gives us, in the course of its first three discs, all but FOUR of the group's released numbers (these being the original, nine-minute version of Stills' \\"Bluebird\\" as well as three tracks from the 1968 LAST TIME AROUND LP). Since none of the CDs runs much over an hour, this is absolutely inexcusable. Alternates and outtakes are fine; but when a band's entire catalogue could easily fit on two discs, to leave a handful of songs off a four-disc anthology is just...well, choose your favorite adjective.<br />  Padding things out instead is a wealth of previously unreleased material, including arguably too many solo demos by Young and transitional recordings which document the Springfield's disintegration into its various members' subsequent careers. Much of this is great stuff, though some of it is rather difficult to call Buffalo Springfield.<br />  The crowning irony, however, is disc four, whereon the first two Buffalo Springfield albums are presented in release order - even though every single one of these tracks with the sole exception (no pun intended) of \\"Mr. Soul\\" appears somewhere on the first three discs. This blatant bit of price-gouging, absurd enough in itself, is doubly awful in light of the tracks left missing from this \\"definitive\\" compilation.<br />  Given that fully half the material on BOX SET consists of rarities, and that all three Springfield albums are easily and cheaply available on CD, this box is clearly aimed at hardcore fans - which is to say, people who want to hear everything. That we don't is, alas, a tragic blight on a potentially (and largely) wonderful collection of music.

B0000560X3|5.0|I will no longer elaborate the merits and history of this great classic rock album. Without hesitation I can say that this is one of the greatest rock albums ever made. But Machine Head just got a lot better with the dvd audio format. The disc comes in two sound formats, the multi channel and high fidelity format. The full multi-channel surround sound of this album can be heard in high fidelity PCM creating a sound field with the ambience and fullness of a live performance. Imagine listening to this album as if Deep Purple is performing in front of you.This sound format is good witha 5.1 speaker system. The second sound format which is my favorite is capable of accurately represent an analog signal in digital form it has a Sample Size of 24 bits and a Sample Rate of 192KHz (24/192),The PCM stereo sound format of this album is capable of reproducing an audio signal with a frequency range of 0 to 96KHz with a dynamic range of 144dB. But in order to enjoy this format one should have a DVD AUDIO PLAYER. Machine Head is Deep Purple's greatest album it just got a lot better with this. This album is essential not just for Classic rock fans but for music lovers in general.

Don't get me wrong, there are more tracks on the album that I enjoy. B0006213WG|3.0|First off, to address the reviewer below me, if you knew anything about Metallica, you'd know that Cliff Lee Burton (greatest metal bassist ever, may he R.I.P.), was CREMATED. Therefore, he isn't in a grave. And I don't see how he'd be specifically mad about \\"The Bitter End\\"; he'd be mad if Sum 41 tried to rip off something like \\"Anesthesia\\" or \\"Orion.\\" The only one that may be mad would be Kirk Hammett, whom Sum 41 copies a lot of his guitar style, particularly, his \\"battery\\" solo. <br /> <br />So onto the actual review, I used to be a big Sum 41 fan about 3-4 years ago. Since then, I've moved onto older rock (Zeppelin, Pink Floyd, the Beatles, the Rolling Stones, AC/DC), metal (Metallica, Iron Maiden, Black Sabbath, Megadeth, Slayer, Judas Priest, and to an extent, Dream Theater and Mastodon), and even REAL punk (The Clash, Sex Pistols, Black Flag, and arguably, Rancid). So having deviated from pop-punk, I decided to listen to this new \\"heavier\\" Sum 41. Now there are definite notable traces of \\"imitation\\": \\"We're all to blame\\" sounds strikingly similar to \\"Chop Suey\\" by System of a Down, and \\"The bitter End\\" has already been noted to be nearly an exact, shorter copy of Metallica's \\"Battery.\\" I find this to be both a good and a bad thing; they are obviously drawing influence from better bands (Metallica, System of a Down, Iron Maiden, etc.) and they prove to be technically proficient to be able to imitate their sound. But its not original; if we wanted to hear incredible Kirk Hammett shredding, we'd listen to old Metallica.  <br /> <br />So in short, this album is not bad, its Sum 41's third best. Their best album would have to be Does This Look Infected?, a darker and angstier sound with metal influence (e.g. \\"No Brains\\" and \\"Hooch\\"), ultimately bordering on the classification of grunge music. Their second best would have to be the horribly underrated Half Hour of Power. This is their third (The horribly overrated mainstream All Killer No Filler, despite its title, is the worst). <br /> <br />There are still notable songs of this CD: \\"We're all to Blame,\\" \\"No Reason,\\" \\"Open Your Eyes,\\" and \\"88.\\" \\"Some Say\\" is more or less a copy of \\"Handle This\\" from All Killer No Filler. <br /> <br />So, hats off to Sum41 for showing they are much more talented than their contemporaries, for showing they can shred guitar solos. But points off for lack of originality. <br />

B000002IST|5.0|We Can't Dance(1991) is probably the best album of Genesis as a trio. It also marks the end of the Phil Collins era. You've got to admit that this is their best effort. The album starts out with the powerful NO SON OF MINE which topped the charts at number twelve. JESUS HE KNOWS ME is one of the more fun songs on the album that talks about television evangelists. DRIVING THE LAST SPIKE is the best song on the album and there hasn't been a Genesis epic this good since 1973. I CAN'T DANCE is the weakest song on the album which sounds like wanna-be ACDC. NEVER A TIME isn't bad but isn't anything to brag about. Now DREAMING WHILE YOU SLEEP is an excellent song that sounds a bit like I Can't Dance but isn't corny. TELL ME WHY is another great song that sounds a bit like the solo songs that Phil Collins does in the years to come. LIVING FOREVER has some prog-rock moments in it and some great guitar by Mike Rutherford. HOLD ON MY HEART is a ballad but not like the messes in the previous album. WAY OF THE WORLD is a swingin' song with great oriental-like keys from Tony Banks. SINCE I LOST YOU is the best Genesis ballad, along with Hold On My Heart. And then comes the grand finale, FADING LIGHTS. This song is appropriate since this is Genesis last good album. Elements of old-school Genesis are in here as well. I think that this album would have been better if it had songs like the edgy ON THE SHORLINE and HEARTS ON FIRE on it. On the Shorline is the best rock song of the 90s in my opinion. This is still a great album but sadly, after this, Genesis really turns bad.

Talented hairbands like Twisted Sister and Motley Crue gave way to crap rip-offs like Warrant and Poison. And on top of that we had that lame pop from Paula Abdul, and dear lord, Color Me Badd. Needless to say, it was a dismal era in music. Then the whole grunge explosion happened in late '91 with the song 'Smells Like Teen Spirit' by Nirvana. Although the topics were often times depressing and had mediocre instrument players, the grunge bands were damn talented and sounded near flawless. Pearl Jam happened to be one of them. Maybe Nirvana started the grunge explosion, but Pearl Jam made it into a new wave of music. Songs like 'Alive', 'Porch', 'Evenflow', and especially 'Jeremy' will grab your attention and make you listen to TEN more than once. B0007Y4TVU|4.0|I am often ridiculed for liking SOAD, mainly because I've somehow managed to root myself deep into \\"emo\\" territory, where the kids are more close-minded about music than people who only listen to rap and rap-affilates. True, SOAD is one of the few 'nu-metal' (if you can even call it that) bands I really enjoy, but the creativity of the whole band just blows my mind every time I hear it. 'Mesmerize' reminds me of Frank Zappa's 'Apostrophe' for some reason, and there are few errors on the record. My main complaint is that Serj does not get to really showcase his amazing singing ability because the guitarist (and co-producer!) really hogs the mic. Serj is what got me into this band; guitarist need to stick to guitar and not try to be the front-man. This is the worst case of vocal-envy I have heard in a long time. Other than that, the album is solid and really rather epic. Anti-war themes are getting to be old-hat, but 'Mesmerize' uses such in-depth ways of stating their postitions that I can't help but wonder sometimes if the album truly does concern war or if it's just a 'fun' album? I think maybe this is what SOAD was going for.
038572179X|5.0|This is an exceptionally well-reviewed novel, so I'm not sure what I can hope to add to the discussion.  In fact, you should probably not read this review any further than the second paragraph if you've not read the book, which makes the review pretty much useless.  That said, I kind of want to talk about the book a little, so here goes.    This is simply an outstanding work of an immesurable talent at the height of his game and powers.  The sense of time and place, the depth of the characters, and the power of the love story that gives much of the novel its backbone make it impossible to put down and difficult to forget.  What also struck me was the author's confidence.  I think many of us at times take a healthy dose of (at times unknowing) skepticism and cynicsm into novels -- particularly novels that make no bones about the fact that they fully intend to manipulate and at times to use unconventional devices.  Reading these kinds of novels often pits the reader against in the author in the early chapters, requiring the author to build a tower of credibility on which the novel's success ultimately depends.  But, for me at least, a writer's confidence in his or her abilities can sometimes shortcut this process, immediately break down the wall of skepticsm and pull you by force into a state of surrender where you can be swept up by the ride.  I thought of two very different authors while I read Atonement, who have done this -- Faulkner and Cormac McCarthy.  McEwan is of course thematically much different from them, but he shares (and more importantly communicates) that kind of confidence, which makes the reader's (or, at least, this reader's) experience that much more rewarding.     Like others of you, I too am a fan of the metafiction elements of this novel.  It's not an accident, I expect, that my two favorite reads this calendar year were this novel and Everything Is Illuminated -- two novels that are as much about writing and writers as they are about what theyare \\"about.\\"  But it comes with something of a cost in this novel; two costs really.  First, I thought it funny that one of the reviews reproduced in the beginning of the book describes McEwan as being \\"invisible\\" during the read.  I disagree entirely.  When a writer writes about a writer, it is virtually impossible for him not to give the reader at least the illusion that he is writing about himself.  And when McEwan critiques or discusses Briony's attempts at writing in the novel, he is plainly critiquing and discussing his own work.  This is an \\"inside baseball\\" aspect to Atonement that causes you while reading to be starkly reminded, \\"hey, I'm reading a novel.\\"  Second, in order to accomplish his novel-in-a-novel surprise, McEwan needs to keep certain details from you until the end.  The most important is to not let you know (again spoiler coming) that Robbie has died.  As a result, he cannot spend even a second having Briony grieve about Robbie (or her sister).  As a result, at the end of the book, Briony is just too reprehensible and ulikeable; while the book does not depend on her likeability (actually quite the opposite), at the end she is simply thoroughly detestable.  Indeed, you learn that many of the parts of the book that give her some likeability were simply things she manufactured about herself and didn't happen. It's always all about her -- right to the end, as a 77 year old, we find a woman luxuriating in her guilt to an absurdly self-absorbed level.    Finally, as great as the story and reading experience are, the take-away questions from this book are a little disappointing.  It essentially asks the question, is there such thing as atonement?  The bleak conclusion is that there is not.  There are acts, crimes, consequences, and guilt.  \\"Atonement,\\" is besides the point, and little more than a fancy word to describe the actor's ability or inclination to forgive herself.  A task that becomes, I guess this novel tells us, both a little more easy anda little more complicated if the actor happens to be a novelist.    So, that small disappointment aside, I loved this book.  It's my first novel by this author, and I can't wait to read the rest.

B000A3DFZE|4.0|Like Van Morrison, many of us have a nostalgic connection to Eric Clapton dating back nearly forty years. We hope that each new record will catapault us back to the emotional sunshine of the 60's and 70's; a return to those days when the music was new and ground-breaking. It isn't to be because it can't be new anymore; but it can be refreshing. This the case with Back Home. Eric Clapton has gotten back to combining blues, reggae and R&B into catchy tunes that leave you satisfied. Perhaps not in a league with Journeyman, Back Home does enter that territory. Although Pilgrim was excellent musically  it was a very difficult record to listen to because of its themes and therefore had a limited repeat-listening lifespan. Reptile lacked punch. The return to his catchy pop sensibilities is quite welcome. We probably won't experience the \\"Oh Wow\\" of a 461 Ocean Boulevard again but this is a fine reminder of how it used to be. This is a fun record and recommended
1593072937|5.0|\\"The Hard Goodbye\\" (originally entitled simply \\"Sin City\\" when first published) tells us (a small part of) the story of Marv, a brute with a heart of gold, a head condition, a face that looks like Baghdad and a taste for stylish coats and witty remarks. We join him as he is about to have the night of his life with Goldie, a \\"goddess\\" who \\"smells like angel's ought to smell\\", and we are just as clueless as he is about how he got there... and who gets to kill her in her sleep. <br /> <br />That's only the first, though, of the many bits of a big and menacing puzzle that we will be piecing together as the story advances. And that's one of the most interesting features of this comic book (all seven volumes): it's not only it's illustrations nor the use it makes of the page-layout, but the very way this more or less simple story is narrated. <br /> <br />Frank Miller says it himself at the very end of this 208-page volume: \\"This one ran away with itself. I'd planned it as forty-eight pages, but I got carried away.\\" And it surely runs like hell: the dark and thrilling story seems to \\"run away with itself\\" just as Marv does at the beginning of the story, and you are almost sad that it has to end at all. Lucky for us, this is only the first of seven. Definitevly a great buy. Five stars. A must read.

B0002OERI0|5.0|American Idiot, while not the most \\"punk\\" of Green Day's albums, is probably their best. One misconception that most people seem to have  is that this is a political album mainly made against Bush. While there is a political edge in a few songs during the album, this is not a political album, but a \\"punk rock opera\\" telling the story of Jesus of Suburbia. Every song on this album is unique, bringing many new aspects to the pop/punk genre. \\"American Idiot,\\" \\"St. Jimmy,\\" and \\"She's a Rebel\\" are typical Green Day songs, while \\"Wake me up When September Ends,\\" and \\"Whatsername\\" tap into the side of Green Day similar to the song \\"Good Riddance.\\" The two nine minute songs \\"Jesus of Suburbia,\\" and \\"Homecoming\\" manage to stay interesting, despite their length. All the songs flow seamlessly into each other, often changing pace dramatically, as in the transition from \\"Are we the Waiting,\\" and \\"St. Jimmy.\\" Overall, this is Green Day's best work to date, despite being very overplayed on the radio and MTV. This album should interest long-time Green Day fans, and people just being introduced to them.

It is he alone who will or will not win the war for the Nazis. The story starts off with Faber in London, where he kills the landlady for bothering him while he was working on his secret transmitter. Faber then has to flee from London for fear of being caught. He heads up north to Scotland to look for more military activity and to rendezvous with a U-boat.  He steals a small fishing boat but gets caught in a storm. Faber's boat is destroyed and he washes up on a small island inhabited by a family. The family consists of a wife, the crippled husband, and their three year old son. The positives were that it held you on the edge of your seat with suspense and thrills. The major drawback of the book is that it took a long time for the action to start happening. Half the book was basically explaining the different characters and setting up what would happen next. I like books that dive right into the action but this was an exception. I like how Mr. Follet went into detail about how a spy thought it was interesting to see how he noticed all of his surroundings and used them to his advantage.  The characters were dynamic and they made for a good story. In short this was a great book and I recommend it for all.

B0006FFRW0|5.0|For the longest time, a friend had been trying to get me to listen to NIN. It wasn't until this year with the release of With Teeth that I came to realize the crazy, methodical and perfectionistic world that was NIN.      The same friend told me that I should check out The Downward Spiral because it was, in his opinion, not only NIN's masterpiece but also a masterpiece of music in general.  Better late than never to try it out, right?  Finding this Dualdisc presentation, digitally remastered and in 5.1, I am amazed.  Talking about the disc itself, the music is crisp and if you listen to it in a 5.1 surround sound player, the songs assault your senses in a sometimes dizzying manner as sounds swing around you.  It helps push the album even further toward the \\"music to listen to\\" mode I'm always looking for.    The songs are terrific, showing Trent's questioning of various standards.  \\"Heresy\\" is funny song in that the lyrics undermine themselves.  But it also questions people's faith today and does so in a great, interesting way.  But not only are the songs dark and full of passion, they invoke different genres of music, sometimes in the same song.  I immediately was shocked and in love with \\"Ruiner\\" when the blues guitar, muffled and electric, blares in with blues licks.  I was amazed and subdued with the only ray of real light on the album, \\"A Warm Place\\" with its peaceful moments before crunching back into full strength.  I was blown away in \\"Pig\\" when the drums came blasting in at the end in the chaotic way that seemed so out of synch with the music but perfectly fit.  And \\"Hurt\\" never sounded so good.  Having only heard it on the radio a couple times (and the Man in Black's version that was overplayed), I can honestly say I heard it for the first real time here.      I'm still a new fan to NIN, coming in late tothe game.  All I've heard is With Teeth and The Downward Spiral.  But, The Downward Spiral is a masterpiece of musical talent in my opinion.  What Trent does best is take chaos and make sense of it.  Like in \\"Pig\\" with the crazy drum work that doesn't seem to fit, he makes it work.  In songs where he samples various things (women's voices etc) and incorporates them with electronica and instruments, he makes sense of chaos.  And this album shows Trent as one of the most talented people in music today.

B000002LK1|5.0|accessability isn't generally the kindest of terms when describing or writing about music.  'violator' is easily depeche mode's most accessible album, full of several of the most memorable moments, and arguably their most memorable single.<br /><br />'enjoy the silence' took depeche mode from darkened basement bedrooms to your suburban house-mom's kitchen. suddenly all the kids that made fun of and laughed at the black-clad mode-aphiles touted depeche mode as their favorite 'new band.' orginally a ballad and juiced up by the sadly-departed alan wilder, 'enjoy the silence' will probably always be depeche mode's signature song.  it's significantly dancier than previous singles, employing an infectious baseline and deceptively simple guitar melody. more than that, it's easily martin's most perfect melody that 15 years on still sounds incredible.<br /><br />'violator,' while generally more optimistic sounding than 'black celebration' and 'music for the masses,' feels darker in both tone and complexity. the electronic bass lines of 'world in my eyes,' 'halo,' and 'the policy of truth' sound sucked out from behind the iron curtain had it still existed when the band released the album.  of course, it doesn't hurt to have flood at the helm.<br /><br />the pefect blend of old and new mode: embracing new, more dance-oriented electronica without sacrificing the tried-and-true, somber, depeche mode ethos.

B00000ILDE|5.0|When Ridley Scott released the monster of \\"Alien\\" back in 1979 a new legend was formed. For 7 years fans wanted to know what happened to Ellen Ripley, and finally, in 1986, the long awaited sequel of \\"Aliens\\" was released. And may I say that it does not disappoint in the slightest! Let me explain dudes...<br /><br />\\"Alien\\" was undoubtedly a Sci-Fi horror as members of the Nostromo were killed off one by one by a hideos black \\"xenomorph.\\" Ellen Ripley is the sole survivor of the incident and escapes by entering an evacuation module and going into hyper-sleep. \\"Aliens\\" picks up over two centuries later when Ripley is awakened after being discovered by another crew and is brought back to Earth. She is soon convinced to join a group of marines in exploring a colony on Aurora-51; a planet that has been besieged by the same monstrous creatures that hunted Ripley. She soon discovers many new things about the creatures and soon finds herself battling survival with the group of marines. A pretty cool storyline I think, and for an action sci-fi it's totally suitable. 9/10 for the storyline.<br /><br />In \\"Alien\\" we believed that these aliens were solitary creatures that hunted and killed in order to survive. \\"Aliens\\" reveals that the aliens are actually creatures that live and co-exist in rather large groups, and that there are various forms of Alien: these range from the common drone, to facehuggers and larvae and a Queen that is the central hub of the hive, much like that of bees. We also learn that the Aliens work to grow and protect the hive and are extremely hostile yet surprisingly intelligent creatures.<br /><br />I'm not sure if this is 100% correct, but the concept of the \\"Dropship\\" seems to have been introduced by \\"Aliens.\\" I haven't seen dropships in earlier movies, so this seems to be one of the very innovative and new ideas that \\"Aliens\\" brought to the genre of Sci-Fi. The Marines also have weapons that are more practically orientated and are believably futuristic. Using laser guns would've made this movie lame, and James Cameron has chosen to maintain the gritty and dark atmosphere of \\"Alien\\" through these advanced projectile weapons. The Smartgun makes its first appearance in this film, along with the Pulse Rifle. Smartguns are able to track and \\"lock\\" onto targets and also have advanced target-friend recognition technology. The uniforms of the marines are also very futuristic and also have a practical feel. Aurora-51 is also an extremely dark planet with a naturally hostile atmosphere (Weyland-Yutani developed \\"Atmosphere Processors\\" to convert hazardous gas-chemicals to breathable air  in order for humans to exist on this planet).<br /><br />The Aliens are kept strongly to the original design and the Queen is a very impressive specimen. The Alien Hive seems to almost live and breathe and appear just as slimy and disgusting as the aliens themselves. Cameron shows his genius as a director by keeping action realistic (in most cases) and his creation of mood and atmosphere through landscapes, lighting, characters, weapons and storyline. You really have to see \\"Aliens\\" to truly understand how truly revolutionary and incredible it is.<br /><br />The movie is a refreshing Sci-Fi Action that is extremely innovative, dark and creative. Cameron has successfully expanded on the \\"Alien\\" franchise and has made a truly interesting and exciting movie. The conflict between Ripley and The Queen near the end is certainly a highlight. Nice to see to overzealous females trying to kick the crap out of each other. What kind of action is better, honestly? And to the guy who found this boring - either you get high on some s*** very often or you are far from a Sci-Fi fan. \\"Aliens\\" is a classic that joins the ranks of \\"Alien\\" as a classic Sci-Fi movie. And anybody who wants to dispute that may want to watch out for fans - we're everywhere, and you never know when we may latch onto your face and plant eggs in your body...<br /><br />\\"Aliens\\" gets a full 100% in my book. Today the storyline may not be highly original, but the creation of atmospheres, action, good acting, tension and creativity makes \\"Aliens\\" a true Sci-Fi Giant. B00020X88O|4.0|I don't even want to guess how many words have been written about this movie.  This movie was two steps from the gutter and yet it was hyped to be the greatest, most moving, almost a religious experience.  But it achieved a success when other flop movies fail to break even, securing it's place in history as a camp classic.  Elizabeth Berkely plays a not too bright hitchhiker named Nomi who comes to Las Vegas with nothing but her dream of becoming a dancer / showgirl.  She shacks up with an earnest, well meaning seamstress named Molly (who was the one and only genuine character in this movie) who works at one of the big Vegas hotels in wardrobe for their entertainment department.  While she's sewing, Nomi goes from being a stripper to being a showgirl, and from there it all goes downhill.  It seems she only got the job thanks to the wants of the lead who is trying to get her in the sack at all times, and eventually Nomi secures her position by preforming for the entertainment director.  Really, did anyone think that a movie about a dimwitted drifter who comes to Vegas to be a dancer / stripper was going to be Ben Hur?  Did anyone think that she was going to live happily ever after even if she did achieve the fame she was seeking in that facet of entertainment?  The answer is no, and it was clearly no from the start.  The gal was a skank without direction when she got there (and her lips! *shudder*), and became a sort of cleaned up skank without direction when she left.  Exactly what makes this or any other movie camp?  There are many layers.  It was a combination of factors here.  It's the seriousness of all participants to make art when it turns out to be drivel.  The flash and glitz of sets reveals the obvious production costs that were lost.  But what really made this a camp sensation was Elizabeth Berkely in the lead role.  As she was on another campy show, Saved By The Bell, for so many years it was with a creepy interest that we all turned to her like that galon the soapbox who started in Behind The Green Door.  Having come from a G rated show for kids (as it was on the Saturday morning cartoon line up) and playing a sort of feminist icon for the junior hich school set, it was quite shocking that she wanted to depart so badly from that image that she would take the role the polar opposite of what she was most known for.  She's not a bad actress, but she played her character the same as she did on Saved By The Bell.  We just can't help but look for glimmers of the smart, wannabe sophisticate she was then, and see a scabbie riden, moneymaker shaking stripper in her place.  They should make a sequel of her joining the Peace Corp going to feed starving children in Asia.  Now that I would pay to see!
B000A7Q2DM|2.0|I'm not going to tell you not to buy this album as everyone has a different taste in music,  I'm simply going to tell you what to expect.   <br /> <br />I remember when I first heard their debut album... I was drawn into the band's completely original style.  They played metal without sounding metal.  They played space rock without diving into the realm of incomprehension.  They were different, which is more than every band coming out of the genre could say, and although they were extremely catchy, 30 Seconds To Mars still played intelligent music: original song arrangements, complex drum patterns, and certainly a unique vocalistic style from Jared Leto.  You felt both refreshed and relieved after listening to the album, knowing that someone playing rock was still trying to be an innovator. <br /> <br />So with high expectations, I popped their new album into my cd player Wednesday night.  Twenty minutes later I found myself listening to their old album again, in order to convince myself I wasn't insane for buying the new one.  Everything that made the first album so interesting and refreshing is missing from \\"A Beautiful Lie.\\"  Leto seems to have lost his taste for experimentation and in effect every song sounds bland and generic, lacking any sort of originality.  Such surprises as the acoustic leadin to the chorus of \\"Edge Of The Earth,\\" the syncopated percussion of \\"Echelon\\"'s intro, the deeply inbedded gasps and yelps of \\"The Mission\\" that made that song so fun to listen to and the sprawling outro of \\"Year Zero\\" that leaves you yearning for more even after two minutes of the same lyrics, are all gone.  All that's to be found are uninteresting drum rhythms, played out guitar patterns, and generic song structures.  As sad as it is for me to say this, 30 Seconds To Mars can now be clumped in with all the Nicklebacks and Puddle of Mudds.  \\"A Beautiful Lie\\" is just simply not an engaging listen.   <br /> <br />So my advice to the reader: If you liked \\"30 Seconds To Mars\\" for it's unique sound and originality, DO NOT BUY THIS ALBUM (well ok, maybe I will say it.)  You will be disappointed I promise.  However, if your a fan of bands such as Seether and Nickleback, you might actually enjoy this album and I do not want to discourage you from buying it.

The 2nd album by Gorillaz, which is not only a hit, but a masterpiece.
B0007Y4TVU|5.0|In a time when alternative metal is dying, System of a Down are the brightest of the few breaths of fresh air in that genre. In fact, the band shouldn't even be classified as they have got their own style, which they triumphantly prove with Mesmerize. <br /> <br />SOAD are by far the most creative and melodic metal band today and they continue to furhter push their musical boundaries. They are muscular, witty, modern, deep, bombastic, intelligent, soulful and cathartic at the same time. Their balance between depth and headbanging reminds Tool's earlier records. And unlike Tool, they manage to pack it into 2-3 minute songs with absolutely no wasted time. The whole album lasts only 36 minutes, but it is just enough - you will get enough impressions and have a feeling of a whole piece of music. <br /> <br />Lyrically, SOAD continue to explore their anti-corporative-America and antiwar views, but alsotouch upon some eternal filosophical problems which is trademark SOAD. What makes the album unique even for this band is the use of vocal harmonies between Serj Tankian and Daron Malakian in almost every song. At times you wold think that Serj had better sung alone, but they are compensated by some terrific moments on tracks 1, 3, 9 and Malakian-sung closer Lost in Hollywood is just as venomous as Rage Against The Machine song while also being lyrical and harmonious. <br /> <br />The production is a step forward from the first two albums; it is so clear and sharp that you can hear every instrument which means you will dicsover more unnoticed details with each consecutive listen. <br /> <br />1. Soldier Side - Intro. This is a harmonious and sad intro to the SOAD's vision of modern world. Eastern-tinged and ehereally beautiful. <br />2. B.Y.O.B. This song kicks ass... A dope phrase, I know, but it's so powerful, explosive, operatic, melodic and entertaining at the same time. What's more, it also manages to melt numerous riffs, melodies and rhythms into one cohesive and expressive whole. <br />3. Revenga. A solid song which has perhaps the best bridge on the album. Daron's vocals are so emotive!... <br />4. Cigaro. This 2-minute masterpiece has got everything... The best funny song SOAD have written so far. <br />5. Radio/Video. An Armenian-tinged track which results in its cool melody. An explosive chorus and a cool solo towards the end make this another highlight. <br />6. This Cocaine Makes Me Feel Like I'm On This Song. Great riffs, superb singing in Serj's style. This is a chaotic track in the vein of Jet Pilot. <br />7. Violent Pornography. Overall, a strong track, but not one of my favourites. <br />8. Question! This is the most operatic song on Mesmerize which means you'll be thrilled by quiet verse/emotive chorus/speedy climax of this song. THIS IS MUSIC. <br />9. Sad Statue. One of my favourites, features awesome polyphonic vocal interplay between Serj and Daron in the verses and a truly epic chorus. <br />10. Old School Hollywood. The use of keyboard effects reveals that SOAD are not Radiohead, but it works to create an empty and pretentious atmosphere - this song is about 'old school Hollywood baseball' ;))) <br />11. Lost In Hollywood. The calmest song on the album, which is melodic and turns almost gothic towards the end. The lyrics sum up the overall topic of the album well.   <br /> <br />Comparing Mesmerize to Toxicity, I should say that it's hard decide which is better as both are awfully strong. While Toxity seems slightly more sprawling and classical alternative metal, Mesmerize is more a whole piece of art and definitely a quintessential SOAD album. Buy this; I recommend this to EVERY person unless he hates hard music. It is and will probably remain this year's best. <br />

B00004XONN|5.0|About 2000 reviews for Radiohead's fourth album and a follow-up to 'OK Computer' - 'Kid A' prove that the band and this recording especially are controversial. And this is a good case, moreover, rightfully so. A truly unique album that is one of the band's best. <br /> <br />What makes 'Kid A' special is the fact that it was the first, and perhaps the most focused fusion of rock and electronica by Radiohead. The first three albums were real progressions from each other and by hte release of 'OK Computer' the band had created an almost perfect record in the genre of alternative guitar rock. They had to take a new direction, and they did it with samples, beats and weird song structures.  <br /> <br />The style alone is of course no big thing, but combined with the quality of the album it achieves a great result. Not as melodic and harder to get into than 'The Bends' and 'OK Computer', the music here is deep, touching and inventive. In fact, 'Kid A's soundscapes could be even more expressive than on 'OKC' if you really get into them. There are occasional guitar songs - Optimistic, In Limbo - but the album as a whole seems different from Radiohead's earlier work. <br /> <br />And yes - 'Kid A' is really a WHOLE, a true blow to your mind. The lyrics, the music and even the booklet art melt together, making this a fully realized piece of art, a terrifying picture of our modern world and what it does to thinking people.  <br /> <br />There are not many albums like this in history. I hope you enjoy it and it helps you discover something new in life.
1573223085|5.0|Daniel Pink presents a coherent and amusing picture of how we need to refocus our educational and training programs to feature more right-brain thinking and incorporation of the arts in design.  He identifies six essential aptitudes needed for the future: Design, Story, Symphony, Empathy, Play, and Meaning. These can be used to organize, explain, and move forward with the data gathered in typical left-brain activites.  Since many people can be trained to do analytical data collection and analysis, it will be the people who can take that information to the next level by using creative problem solving and original designs who will succeed in the future.
B000002UR7|3.0|Radiohead's first album is generally considered immature and their worst, at least by fans of their later work. It also has the lowest sales rank on Amazon, so you could really start doubting about the quality of this recording. <br /> <br />And - strange to say this about Radiohead - it is a subpar offering by band's standards and an average album overall. At that time Radiohead were not unique - they played generic guitar Britpop with some U2 influences that were yet to be fully realized and integrated into their sound - nor did they have accomplished songwriting which results in the album's inconsistence.  <br /> <br />The lack melody and sometimes indulge in unexpressive instrumental sections (Stop Whispering, I Can't) that seem to be nothing but unnecessary noise. Tom's lyrics are not as sharp and original as expected; in fact, they are generic like the album's sonic palette. <br /> <br />What luckily saves Pablo Honey LP are its highlight songs: Creep, Radiohead's first hit that became a clichee for the band; Anyone Can Play Guitar, a grungey but uplifting gem and Blow Out - a haunting dynamic jam that established the tradition of strong album closers. Other songs worth mentioning include You, Thinking About you and Vegetable. <br /> <br />I would recommend this album for the fans of early-ninetees guitar rock and of course to the Radiohead fans looking to comlplete their collection. Others should first check 'The Bends', 'OK Computer' or 'Kid A'.

The Robert Johnson sets returned Eric to his roots and reminded him what great songwriting sounds like. Back Home is Eric Clapton at his best. There will be those who never will forgive EC for leaving Mayall's band, much less Cream, and haven't given any validity to his work since 461 Ocean Blvd. provided the template for the rest of EC's career. They will hate this CD, just as they hated Reptile, Pilgrim, Journeyman, etc.<br /><br />Back Home is full of warm lyrics set to upbeat melodies. Musically, the songs are just as easy-going as a summer afternoon. You'll be humming along before you know it.<br /><br />My advice to those who will be disappointed that there is not a Crossroads XXV on the disc - grow up. EC has, and he shows maturity and an appreciation for the truly important things in life on Back Home.

0517221160|5.0|I read Little Women when I was a Little Woman.  I just recently decided to buy it for my daughter and read it again.  What a classic!  This is a must for anyone's reading list both male and female.  The story chronicles the March family, in particular one of the daughters, Josephine March.  It is a story of hope and love.  This is not a love story of romance, but one of tender, unconditional love that exists in a family of a mother, father and four very different daughters.  There are moral lessons throughout the book that are refreshing and the character of all the girls comes through vividly.  Alcott does a wonderful job devloping the different personalities of her characters.  There are lessons for young people written between the lines on strength, wisdom, love, patience and quiet service.  Boys and girls alike will benefit from the examples of polished and refined manners.  A beautifully wirtten story that well deserves the label of a Classic.<br />Just a note about this particular copy--We like to buy classics that are nicely bound and not cheap looking. Avenged Sevenfold has done what no other band in their genre would even consider to do, and they have created a masterpeice in the process. B000002J0P|5.0|Back in 1969, my friend Ed (always ahead of the curve when it comes to new music) pointed to the overhead speaker in the student cafeteria and said, \\"Track of the year.\\" The college radio station was playing Judy Blue Eyes. I stopped, gave a listen and skipped lunch so I would have money to buy the album on the way home (no plastic back then.)  I still have the record and I also have the CD. This record helped me through long hours studying for Dr. Peg's Organic Chem class.  I just put the headphones on and shut out the world, calmed by some of rock's finest voices, inspired guitar playing and that sweet, sweet harmony. So much rock music has come and gone since '69 - some of it good, some of it flat out dreck, but there are few if any records as musically involvng as CSN's first. This is a classic that belongs in every rock collection. Make sure to listen to the words - they are simple and simply amazing.

B00006SFBD|5.0|Deliverance is  the album that introduced Opeth to me. I spent a lot of time thinking whether I liked Blackwater or Deliverance more, and it is really hard to make a choice. I have pre-ordered Ghost Reveries and still waiting, so I do not know what shall happen next in my Opeth favorites list. <br /> <br />Notwithstanding my indecisiveness for the best Opeth album, I believe Deliverance is the most progressive, developed and most accomplished album of Opeth in terms of song structure, production and sound. Especially the drums are much more creative and independent in this album when compared to Blackwater or any other Opeth album.  <br /> <br />I think this album includes the best of Lopez, not only performance wise, but also sound wise. But in Deliverance, he leads the band and gets a huge part in the being creative department. The drums in Deliverance have really a story to tell. In the final part of the song \\"Deliverance\\", we witness an incredible rhythmic progression by Lopez. The added splashes and chinas onto the already repeated rhythm, added a lot of spice for those who can appreciate. Lopez is definitely one of the best drummers around. Add a bit of more power to his playing and a couple of signature fills and rhythms and he would be a trademark. His contribution is immense. <br /> <br />As for the songs, Wreath is like a big fist in your face and keeps hammering you for the remaining 10+ minutes even toughit also contains some really beautiful mellow parts, one of the best Opeth songs ever. However the second song, Deliverance is, in my point of view, the best Opeth song ever. You should listen to it so that I do not have to struggle to define it. Especially the final part of the song...I call it a masterpiece...A Fair Judgment is also one of my favorites. Great vocals and great vocal melodies...Master's Apprentice starts with a cool riff and builds its way from there-definitely one of the favorites of the album. By the Pain I See in Others is the one song that I couldn't get very much into... <br /> <br />I don't see a lot of bands around today, which possess all the key ingredients to make a perfect rock band; a loyal fan base, high instrument skills, original, creative and honest song writing, and a non-compromising philosophy. There are certain songs where love even takes the backseat--i.e. \\"Big Exit,\\" \\"Kamikaze,\\" \\"Horses in my Dreams\\"--focusing instead on self-actualization and disillusionment. In fact, as the title implies, these songs are stories of isolation and alienation within metropolitans and seashores that all seem the same. 0679416781|1.0|I made it halfway through this book before giving up on it.  As an avid reader, I seldom put a book down.  I just couldn't find anything to compel me to finish this one.  At the mid-point, I still felt that the characters were being introduced - endlessly.  In a character study, I expect to know something about what is going on in the heads of the characters, but aside from brief flashbacks inserted randomly into the text, you are told nothing about what is in the characters minds.  Occasionally, they are said to look mournful, or pensive, etc, but however picturesque the descriptions are, they are no substitute for mental activity or plot.  If the author's intention was to paint an outside portrait of the survivors of a war, that was accomplished.  There is a strange other-worldly disconnected feel to the characters.  You can feel their isolation from world; but it makes for a one-note read.  There is a patina of unreality to their world that reads almost like a fairy tale - but one where nothing happens.  The characters seem to be stuck in an amber of PTSD.  Most of the book to the halfway point was just very nicely written descriptions of their day to day life.  How they bathed, what they ate, which room they slept in, etc.  Basically, this book was like watching a silent drama.  You could see what they were doing, and what they were remembering, but there was no significant action going on, and no way to get in their heads.  It was kind of like trying to do psychoanalysis on a picture.

B000002L99|5.0|\\"5150\\"(1986). Van Halen's seventh album,and their first album with Sammy Hagar on lead vocals. <br /> <br />By the mid 1980's,Van Halen had left the 70's being one of the most influential and succesful rock bands around. The only problem was that VH lead singer David Lee Roth had become egotistical and hard to work with and decided to quit the band--meaning that Eddie Van Halen,Alex Van Halen,and Michael Anthony were going to have to recruit a new lead singer for VH. As we all know,the singer they chose was Sammy Hagar,and the question you are already asking yourself is if Van Halen were still a good band when Sammy Hagar was their lead singer. Read on for my review of this: <br /> <br />To answer my first question,Van Halen were still a good band when Sammy Hagar was their lead vocalist(I like DLR better than Hagar--although I do like Hagar)and this album gave a nice rebirth to Van Halen. Outdated as it is,it still is a really good album. It(this album)sounds like leftovers from Montrose,Sammy Hagar's solo material,and Van Halen's last album with David Lee Roth(1984)and it sounds really good. And this is pretty much a great album from start to finish--Sammy Hagar tryed to get Van Halen get to new heights in their career,and he did a good job at that. The songwriting here sounds really good,and like I already said,I prefer David Lee Roth over Sammy Hagar,but when Sammy Hagar became the lead singer of Van Halen,VH became a whole new band. Alex Van Halen uses electronic 80's drums on this CD,and they sound really goodon here. Again,this album is outdated,but it still is really good. <br /> <br />Overall,one of the best CDS of the 80's,and a must have CD for any fan of Van Halen(or,Van Hagar).  I would venture to call this a hair metal record,and one of the best CDS of the 80's as well. Hopefully Van Halen and Sammy Hagar will make a new,decent studio album soon.
B00008A7QK|4.0|\\"Electric Warrior\\" was the first T Rex album as a 4-piece band. Originally Bolan called his duo Tyrannosaurus Rex, and the sound was mostly acoustic. With the 2 1970 singles \\"Ride a White Swan\\" and \\"Hot Love\\" Bolan and producer Tony Visconti had found a fatter sound, which proved be what was needed to give Bolan his big break-through.<br /><br />\\"Electric Warrior\\" was recorded over a period when the band was touring in America and the songs were recorded in various different studios in both England and the States. Nevertheless there is a very consistent sound on this album, which with the follow-up , \\"The Slider\\", turned out to be his artistic and commercial highlights.<br /><br />This is glam rock at its very best. The riff from \\"Get it On\\" has been copied by numerous bands since its release, and the song itself has become a classic.<br /><br />Even though the instrumentation and the song-structures are relatively simple, Tony Visconti's production, using various strings, gives Bolan's songs a full and big sound.<br /><br />The opening track \\"Mambo Sun\\", though probably one of the weaker tracks, features some of the charcteristics of the great album - Bolan unique guitar and the great vocals of Flo and Eddie ( from the Turtles and Frank Zappa )<br /><br />First highlight is \\"Cosmic Dancer\\", which has been given quite a big production - great song.<br /><br />The hit-single \\"Jeepster\\" is simply irressistibly catchy!<br /><br />\\"Monolith\\" is so full of atmosphere!<br /><br />The slow heavy blues \\"Lean Woman Blues\\" is probably my least favourite song on the album; good that it's followed by the great \\"Get in On\\"<br /><br />\\"Planet Queen\\" and \\"Girl\\" are like \\"Monolith a spacey ballads; both soulful and catchy.<br /><br />\\"The Motivator\\" is more or less a \\"Get it On\\" rip off; still a good track.<br /><br />\\"Life's a Gas\\" is a great slow rocker, The closing track \\"Rip Off\\"\\" is the wildest rocker on the album.<br /><br />The bonus tracks are all \\"work in progress\\" takes of \\"Warrior\\" songs. B000AADYRQ|5.0|Death Cab's 2003 release of \\"Transatlanticism\\" was monumental. The CD was unequivocally focused, vocally cool, lyrically beatiful, and musically sound. How the album manages to average anything less than 5 stars is beyond me. The wonder of Death Cab is nothing new. They have always been a good band. \\"The Photo Album\\" to \\"Transatlanticism\\" was a bridge between a good and an amazing album, respectively. \\"Plans\\" does not reivent the band's talent, though it, at the very least, reaffirms it. Compared to Transalanticism, Plans is less unified. It does not convey a singe, unified message. Another difference is the sound. Plans focuses on a deep, reverberant sound explored similarly by artists like Frou Frou/Imogen Heap. As it is for such musical style, you will need a good audio system to fully appreciate the depth (as stated in another review). Lyrically, Ben is just as competent as he has always been. If you liked any of Death Cab for Cutie's first 5 albums, you will like this one more. If you liked their 6th album (transatlanticism), then you will have already bought \\"Plans\\" since you realized what a masterpiece the band had created in their prior album.   sidenote: Some have been concerned about a dumbed-down mainstream album succeeding the band's major label signing. The label has in no way noticeably changed the Death Cab style. On the contrary, the seamless production of the album adds a depth that the pre-transatlanticism albums didn't have.  Indie rockers and OC groupies enjoy!

Chow's film is at once a loving tribute to and canny summary of the past 35 years of Chinese martial art cinema. KFH is also hysterically funny and the one kung fu DVD I'd gladly show to someone who was not a fan of the genre. The film is beautifully shot and cleverly scripted. It contains old school fight choreography along with marvelous wire-work stunts and up-to-the-minute CGI effects. The cast, mostly unknowns or lesser players in Chinese cinema, is a pure joy and includes several bona fide kung fu masters in key roles. There is really nothing in Chow's previous films that would hint he is capable of creating such a wonderful entertainment. If you didn't see this one in the theaters, stop reading and buy this DVD now. <br /> <br />Note 1: Despite the R rating, I'd be willing to show this gem to pre-teens. With the exception of the first few minutes, the violence is either wildly cartoonish or standard action film fare. <br /> <br />Note 2: As with almost all foreign language films, I recommend watching it in its original language with English subtitles even if an English language track is available. Dubbing is just too damned distracting and can ruin a good movie like this one. <br />

At the heart of her message is that a baby should be treated with respect.<br /><br />Some readers will find her information helpful.  Others may become frustrated in trying to follow her methods. 0143034901|3.0|Many have equated The Shadow of the Wind to Umberto Eco and Victor Hugo.  I believe a more apt comparison is to Charles Dickens.  This novel is rich in gothic detail.  The mood is as expertly crafted as Bram Stoker's opening chapters of Dracula.  The language is often witty and beautiful.  There are many literary references.  The character Fermin is in many ways the highlight of the novel with his many outrageous and hilarious statements.  Aspects of this character often reminded me of Ignatius J. Reilly from John Kennedy Toole's A Confederacy of Dunces.<br /><br />This book is at its core a love story, and that is where my problems with it lie.  There is no major indication from the jacket, cover, or quotes that this will be a love story.  Some have criticized the age of the characters and the level of their emotions.  I have to agree with those criticisms.  The devastation and power of emotion we experience as teenagers in \\"love\\" is recognized as trivial as we mature.  Carlos Ruiz Zafon seems not to have reached this same understanding.  Also, despite much beautifully crafted imagery, the author occasionally repeats phrases on the same page.  Perhaps this is due to the translation, but I found this repetition amaturish and annoying.  One final criticism, the Mont Blanc pen in the novel is referred to as Meinsterstuck multiple times.  This should have been Meisterstuck (the German word for masterpiece).

0385486804|5.0|What drives some human beings to take extraordinary risks, push the envelope, explore the frontier? When they succeed, we celebrate them as heroes, pathfinders, pioneers. But when they fail, we mock them as reckless, nave or maybe insane.<br /><br />Jon Krakauer has crafted a highly detailed and readable account of one such lone adventurer, Chris McCandless, who from an early age marched to a different drummer. McCandless's wanderlust and idealism drew him to reject the links to the civilized world of rules, protocols and inherited lore for raw, unfiltered first-person experience. He was attracted to the road, the desert, the trackless waste. At age 24, he hitched and hiked to a remote Alaskan field to test himself against nature. 112 days later, he had starved to death, leaving in his wake a devastated family and countless questions about his motives.<br /><br />Krakauer pieces together McCandless's story from his writings, family interviews as well as testimony from the many truckers, drifters and other marginal types who met McCandless in his last months. They recall his enormous charm, his stubbornness, his hatred of externally imposed rules. Then there's his idealized regard for the world of adventure found in books by Jack London and Thoreau - men who seldom lived the life they lauded in print. Krakauer resists the temptation to paint McCandless as an empty-headed idealist. McCandless, after all, managed to survive nearly four months in a land that would have conquered most of us inside of a week. The real story of Chris's character and his death is more complex, and a bit less comforting.<br /><br />Is there a longing wired into the brains of some people to disregard comfort in search of an ultimate life-test? Krakauer has a personal reason for writing the book. He sees in McCandless an echo of his own youthful itch to test himself alone against nearly impossible odds - to achieve something no one else has done. The urge seems to puzzle Krakauer, and McCandless's trek seems the perfect vehicle for the exploring the phenomenon.<br /><br />Interestingly, my teenage son hated the book; he found McCandless's lack of common sense and his rejection of good advice a serious obstacle. But I was fascinated by the book, finding it difficult to put down. McCandless reminded me very much of St. Francis of Assisi, another young man who rejected a life of comfort and privilege for a life of poverty and holy misery and who found his muse in the natural world. Francis too died relatively young, but for a millennium has inspired thousands of others to follow in his footsteps. I also can't help hearing echoes of Christ's temptations in the desert. Can the drive that leads one young man to a lonely death in the Alaskan wild lead another to scale peaks to spiritual heights, or to discover new lands? Is there, should there, be a bit of Chris McCandless in each of us?cCandless's trek seems the perfect vehicle for the exploring the phenomenon. <br /> <br />Interestingly, my teenage son hated the book; he found McCandless's lack of common sense and his rejection of good advice a serious obstacle. But I was fascinated by the book, finding it difficult to put down. McCandless reminded me very much of St. Francis of Assisi, another young man who rejected a life of comfort and privilege for a life of poverty and holy misery and who found his muse in the natural world. Francis too died relatively young, but for a millennium has inspired thousands of others to follow in his footsteps. I also can't help hearing echoes of Christ's temptations in the desert. Can the drive that leads one young man to a lonely death in the Alaskan wild lead another to scale peaks to spiritual heights, or to discover new lands? Is there, should there, be a bit of Chris McCandless in each of us?
0385338686|4.0|This book was delightful - fast-paced, interesting, laugh out loud funny, and romantic, too. Basically, Samantha Sweeting is a high-powered attorney who is up for promotion to partner at her firm. But, when she makes a careless error, she finds herself an outcast at her firm, with friends, and even with her mother. But, her life begins anew when she is mistaken for a housekeeper in another town, and her once frenetic life as a lawyer is forgotten, as she learns to complete simple domestic chores for her employers. The plot is completely ridiculous - I cannot even fathom a person as smart as Samantha agreeing to scrub toilets and like it, but the story makes for a nice read and contains some really funny scenes (mostly in the kitchen, where most of Samantha's mishaps occur). Lucky for Samantha, her employers also have a beefcake gardener on staff (Nathaniel), and he serves as her romantic interest and caretaker. The story was fun, although the last 3 or 4 chapters were rather offputting, because they were so hectic and ill-conceived. It seemed as though the author didn't have a nice way to end the story and everything was jumbled together hastily. Overall, it was worth reading and I'd recommend it!

B000001FN3|5.0|In the words of Alan Parsons himself on the liner notes, \\"We never expected the Alan Parsons Project to become the name of an act.  The phrase was designed to describe the identity of the album you are now holding.\\"  Tales of Mystery and Imagination is the first and, in my opinion, still the best work of the Project.  Every song is inspired by a specific work of Edgar Alan Poe.  The first half consists of great rock songs with catchy licks, top-notch musicianship and very high production values.    The second half is dominated by the orchestral piece \\"The Fall of the House of Usher\\".  I have no idea why the liner notes don't credit Claude Debussy on this piece.  Much of the orchestral parts in Parsons' Usher, including Prelude are adapted from parts of a 2-act opera of Debussy (also called the Fall of the House of Usher) which was unfinished at the time of his (Debussy's) death.  The manuscript was partially reconstituted separately by two composers in 1976 just before the Project put out this album.  For the Parsons score of Usher, Andrew Powell wrote new sections, as well as added sound effects and electronic instrumentation, which adds to the atmosphere, tension and overall power of the piece.    For those who are interested, Amazon lists, but does not have in stock, a CD with a version of the Debussy opera.  It is coupled with The Mask of the Red Death (listed by Amazon as \\"Fantastic Tale\\") by Andre Caplet which is a piece for harp and orchestra inspired by Poe's tale of the same name and which is an amazing, spooky piece that sends shivers up my spine every time I listen to it.    As with many reviewers I also own the original vinyl copy of Tales from its first release and listed to it steadily over the years until this CD came out.  However, perhaps I am in the minority in that I prefer this latter CD with the extra guitar solos, the Welles narration and overall cleaner sound.  In any event this is one of the best (progressive) rock albums ever released and would likely make it on my \\"Desert Island Disks\\" list.

0061015725|4.0|In the novel Prey, written by best selling author Michael Crichton, Crichton manages to create villains who are microscopic. At the same time he manages to keep the story intriguing. The story maintains its thrill throughout all the pages, from when Jack Foreman is suspecting his wife to be having an affair, to the final part when he is escaping a burning building of nanotechnology. Crichton does a great job of building the suspense up then bringing something else out of the bag. This leads one thing on to the next; keeping the story spontaneous. A great example is when Jack sees another man in the car with his wife. When the car crashed, the man is not seen in sight, but a van of Xymos is there. This leads Jack to think about his wife's work, and what she is up to there. Though Prey is a truly juicy story, it also has its flaws. In order to understand the concept in the story, Crichton was to give information on the nano-technology which was causing his wife to have an affair, and his ex-company to go down in ruins. The science in this novel about the technology and the cloning at times left the story dry and boring as if it were an academic class. But at times this story was a great read. A reader could gain much information about technology and the harms of it by reading this story. Though technology helps a great amount in life, it can also be more of a danger. In conclusion, the suspense in the story overrides its flaws causing it to be a great novel. I recommend this book to readers who enjoy science fiction, learning about technology, and those who do not get bored effortlessly.

B0006VIE4C|5.0|\\"A long time ago, in a galaxy far, far away...\\"<br /><br />From the moment these words filled up the screen to ecstatic audiences in May of 1977, a legend was born.  That's a pretty clich&eacute; way of putting it (since, chronologically, this happens to be the fourth chapter in the saga), but there is some serious truth behind the impact that this, the original STAR WARS, left upon many viewers.  It's hard to believe that this movie ever got made, too.  It was George Lucas's brainchild project since childhood, but when shooting this movie, he ran into production problem after problem after problem--many executives predicted that STAR WARS would die at the box office.  And now look at what place it has in the history of moviegoers.  If STAR WARS had not been the megahit that it was, there would be no sequels, no prequels, no fans going around reciting memorable quotes from the movie (\\"May the force be with you!\\"), and, well, all that it is.<br /><br />Looking upon STAR WARS, or should I say, EPISODE IV:  A NEW HOPE, it really is not hard to understand why this film became such a status of pop culture.  Sure, it doesn't have the flashy graphics of today's big, loud and noisy CGI films (although this reincarnation does; more on that later)--but what makes this movie such a classic is simply because, at heart, it is great FUN.  The storyline is epic and action-packed (those starship battles and the climactic Death Star Trench fight are always fresh every time), the atmosphere that Lucas created is imaginative and engaging, and, best of all, it has a cast of characters that have quickly become household names--eager, earnest young hero Luke Skywalker; dashing, courageous Captain Han Solo; tempestuous yet regal Princess Leia; furry Wookie Chewbacca; wise, saintly Obi-Wan Kenobi; ruthless helmeted villain, Darth Vader; and of course, those lovable robots (sorry, droids), C-3PO and R2-D2.<br /><br />It helps, too, that talented performers bring this eccentric cast to life.  Indeed, it is hard to imagine a better trio than Mark Hamill, Harrison Ford, and Carrie Fisher as the three human leads, Alec Guiness as the elderly Jedi Master, Anthony Daniels as the golden, worrisome robot, or even James Earl Jones' memorably stentorian voice as Vader (one of cinema's greatest vocal performances ever).  Say what you will about George Lucas' directing abilities, but these guys bring an infectious, lasting appeal to their roles that it makes those in the prequels pretty stiff by comparison.<br /><br />Equally memorable is John Williams' soundtrack, the title fanfare has been used in every STAR WARS movie to date, and of course, the motifs Williams creates for the characters fit them to a T.  One can only imagine the atmosphere of STAR WARS had it been scored by someone else....<br /><br />With all this, and more, it's no wonder that STAR WARS's impact is still going strong, and, at the risk of causing controversy, the original trilogy can easily hold its own against some of the more cinematically complex and impressive trilogies of our time such as THE LORD OF THE RINGS, THE GODFATHER, and BACK TO THE FUTURE.<br /><br />However, George Lucas wasn't satisfied with his original version of STAR WARS (the miniscule budget he received could hardly be enough to develop some of the story's more ambitious scope), so in 1997, he and his company, LucasFilm Ltd., re-released the film as a \\"Special Edition\\".  This version consists of some added-in and/or altered scenes as well as some more enhanced visual effects.  Purists have opposed these additions, especially since Lucas has not decided to release the original print of STAR WARS on DVD.  While this is a valid argument, Lucas himself has stated that this revamp of A NEW HOPE is HIS vision.  But I don't want to get into the fan controversy about the Special Editions.  On this account, I will say that watching this more beefed-up version is a treat in and of itself; it's interesting (and fun) to pinpoint the differences between the original and the new incarnations.  Admittingly, some of the added-in stuff isn't really necessary (in particular, I COULD probably have done without the altered scene where Greedo shoots first at Han, although I'm not nearly as anal about it as others are), but they hardly affect the flow of the story and just add another level of enjoyment to the experience.<br /><br />For this DVD release of A NEW HOPE (which coincides with the DVD release of the original trilogy), the movie has been tinkered with yet again, this time to fix some of the more glaring flaws that were present in the Special Editions.  Although it's not completely perfect (I did notice some matte-boxing around some of the starships in some shots), this version is about as good as it can get.  Yes, I would like a chance to own the original on DVD as well, but this presentation is still excellent--the hard work that went into the visual and aural restoration is very commendable and is especially spectacular if you have a widescreen TV or state-of-the-art sound system.<br /><br />No matter which version it is presented in, though, STAR WARS is still, well, STAR WARS.nt the differences between the original and the new incarnations.  Admittingly, some of the added-in stuff isn't really necessary (in particular, I COULD probably have done without the altered scene where Greedo shoots first at Han, although I'm not nearly as anal about it as others are), but they hardly affect the flow of the story and just add another level of enjoyment to the experience. <br /> <br />For this DVD release of A NEW HOPE (which coincides with the DVD release of the original trilogy), the movie has been tinkered with yet again, this time to fix some of the more glaring flaws that were present in the Special Editions.  Although it's not completely perfect (I did notice some matte-boxing around some of the starships in some shots), this version is about as good as it can get.  Yes, I would like a chance to own the original on DVD as well, but this presentation is still excellent--the hard work that went into the visual and aural restoration is very commendable and is especially spectacular if you have a widescreen TV or state-of-the-art sound system. <br /> <br />No matter which version it is presented in, though, STAR WARS is still, well, STAR WARS.
