0792833236|5.0|In 'Raging Bull' Scorcese does with ease what most film-makers would find exceedingly difficult, to make us take pity on, and to like, a seemingly unlikeable character.     De Niro's depiction of Jake LaMotta is mind blowing and is surely one that would rank in any top ten. De Niro's method acting reaches it's pinnacle here in a role that he absolutely lived and breathed for over a year. His dedication to the part, coupled to the fact that it was he who brought the story to Scorcese's attention, makes this fine cinematic achievement as much his as it is Scorcese's.    The award winning editing links this film together beautifully, nowhere is this more evident than in the fight scenes. The physical and often emotional battering that Jake takes in these fights are so fantastically and graphically rendered, that you find yourself thinking never has beauty seemed so hideous.    LaMotta's self abusing and self destructing nature turns a story of success and riches into one of despair, lonliness and failure. His quote from 'On the waterfront' in the last scene is fitting but is also indicative of where the stories of the two famous characters separate. LaMotta got the breaks that Terry Molloy didn't but he threw them away. He will not get a second chance and will not get the reprieve in dignity that Molloy did, as LaMotta is a man who has been knocked to the mat and is out for the count.
0399152717|5.0|Will there be any plot-twist that will stun you in the pages of this latest Cussler/Kemprecos tale featuring Kurt Austin?  Nope.  Did I enjoy it just as much anyway?  Yup.  The storyline follows the tried and true Cussler formula that was earlier virtually perfected long ago with the Dirk Pitt novels: begin the story long ago with an amazing event, and somehow manage to tie it together with events of today.  Sure 'nuff, this latest tale does exactly that, and since they followed everything tried and true, I just knew I was in for a fun ride.<br /><br />Now since I am NOT any kind of scientist or mathemetician, the explanations about the possibility of an actual shift in the magnetic poles of the planet certainly seemed plausible to me.  If of course you understand that kind of science, well you may find some kind of glaring error, but I happily did not.  Instead I found the science behind Polar Shift to be pretty convincing.<br /><br />Did a WWII era scientist actually discover a way to shift the Poles using electromagnetic energy (at least I think that is what they used...)?  He certainly seemed genuine to the military minds of Russia and Germany that they wanted him to develop a weapon for themselves.  A daring escape saves Lazlo Kovacs life and before long, he finds himself in America and hopefully all his theorums lost for good, too dangerous to be left in the hands of the governments of ANY country.  Unfortunately a few unsavory people come across these long lost theories and begin to run experiments which cause havoc on weather patterns and possible irreversible catastrophic damage to the earth.  They also mistakenly believe that they can reverse the damage once it begins, but nobody apparently knows this for certain.  The plans and the backstory as to why this corporation embarks on such a horrible plan are also quite interesting to the storyline.  Lets just say if you dislike the so-called *Elites* in the world, you actually may root for the bad guys -- at least for part of the novel.<br /><br />Anyway, the grand daughter of Lazlo Kovacs unknowingly is a pawn in the grand scheme of the featured bad guys in 'Polar Shift'.  Does she know the antidote to the Theorums developed by Kovacs?  If she does, she is completely unaware of them.  Inject an additional side story involving the possible cloning of extinct Wooly Mammoths and you've got a novel worthy of Clive Cussler.  I believe that Clive only comes up with the storylines for these books and that Paul Kemprecos actually writes the stories, and whether or not he actually does, the end results are almost always equal to most of the Dirk Pitt tales of the past 12 years or so...heck, Dirk actually makes an appearance in this book by the way.  In short, if you have enjoyed the previous NUMA novels featuring Kurt Austin, add this one to your collection and you won't be disappointed.- at least for part of the novel. <br /> <br />Anyway, the grand daughter of Lazlo Kovacs unknowingly is a pawn in the grand scheme of the featured bad guys in 'Polar Shift'. B00025ETIW|3.0|You know, many of you probably aren't old enough to realize this, but music goes in cycles. There will always be your \\"arthouse\\" groups, your \\"boyband\\" groups, and your \\"popular\\" groups. My Chemical Romance falls into the latter category. Here's an analogy, My Chemical Romance is to 2005 music what Def Leppard or Motley Crue were to 1980s music. It's asinine lyrics, a manufactured image , but so catchy you'll find yourself singing along or tapping your feet to many songs. This is the kind of music that is needed sometimes. <br /> <br />Now I'll be the first to admit I'm sick of people trying to look like Roberth Smith and play depressing \\"goth\\" music like Joy Division. There are many bands with singers who can't sing to save their lives, but get by on the look that is popular at the moment (I don't want to mention any names...Good Charlotte). My Chemical Romance is riding a wave of the screamo bands that have gotten big lately, and I will be honest, the lead singer can't sing to save his life. The 6th song, it's a slow ballad type song, and it just does not work. I actually started laughing when I first heard it, it's like hearing Papa Roach or Limp Bizkit try to sing ballads, you just have to laugh. My Chemical Romance is good at one thing: writing catchy songs that make people feel like they're writing the songs just for them. Having some tough times in your life and feel alone? \\"I'm Not OK\\" is for you. Lost someone close to you? Try \\"Helena\\". It's not supposed to be Radiohead, so don't treat it as such. <br /> <br />There's always going to be a market for the teenager type music that connects with 15 year old kids who are going through hell because the girls they like don't like them. I grew up with Blink and No Doubt, I have nothing to brag about. This music connects with people, whether it's stupid or not, that's what music is supposed to do. Just enjoy it and don't take it too seriously.
B000005RFQ|4.0|Well, boys & girls... What a distinctive Sabbath chapter this is! You may call it the begining of the end, but this was the most mistreated Sabb album at that point. The downside was the absolutely miserable production which is quite unacceptable for a band who, more than once, brought us cutting edge sound. Even I regard it as a rush job: I believe that the guitar solos on \\"Trashed\\" are too loud, the drums sound like they were recorded from a different room to the mics, blah, blah ,blah...  Ahem!... ANYWAY... The front cover is considered one of the most horrible, ugliest piece of album (f)artwork (source: KERRANG's top 10 worst album sleeves - \\"Born Again\\" is #2, the golden spot being occupied by the Scorpions' \\"Lovedrive\\"). The story behind this regrettable sleeve is actually quite interesting, personally I never understood people who would listen to an album or look at a work of art and say \\"It's a joke!!!\\". Well the \\"Born Again\\" artwork IS a joke... literally!... Steve Joule, who designed it used to work for Ozzy Osbourne and when the latter fell out with Sharon's father the other latter seeked revenge by stealing as many of the Osbourne staff as he could for Black Sabbath. Since Steve didn't want to lose harmony with the Osbournes, he purposefully came up with the most tasteless, dispicable piece of trash he could think of. He took a photograph from a learning magazine (and believe me, when you've seen the original, the Joule version looks quite nice), stuck on the most horrible colors, horns, eyes and fingernails... Sadly, Mr. Iommi loved it and the rest is history... and the band was history. The most ludicrous consequence of this prank was the midget in the devil-baby suit who would jump off the stonehenge stage set and land on a matress... that was once inadvertently removed... OUCH!  So the cover is also a founder of an infamous line of BABY ROCK COVERS featuring Nirvana's \\"Nevermind\\" and Papa Roach's \\"Lovehatetragedy\\".  This is the very last studio albumwith Bill Ward on drums, sadly. He was unable to join the tour due to ill health and was replaced by Bev Bevan.  Most people complain about Ian Gillan's unusual screaming, but I believe that he was only aiming at a different approach. Frankly, I think that joining Black Sabbath was the worst thing that could have happened to Ian for the aforesaid reasons.  The Black Sabbath remasters are quite fun, however it's a shame they didn't include any bonus tracks since there are countless gems from the \\"Born Again\\" session that were never once released. \\"The Fallen\\" is the first track that springs in mind. This album might have been considerably more successful if it had a more polished production and tracklisting.    Well this review is going on a bit, so I'll end it once I've said that \\"Born Again\\" may not reach the standards of its predecesors, but you should still give it a shot.    Cheers!

B000062YAZ|1.0|First off let me introduce myself, I am a huge metal fan and am into bands like Iron Maiden, Black Sabbath, Judas Priest (including the thrashy painkiller) and megadeth etc, and am not going to compare this to the Beatles. People often call this album the best thrash album of all time and I could never figure it out. There is no way in heck this compares to great albums like Megadeth's rust in peace, which actually was a highly precise thrash classic. Instead Kerry King and Jeff Hanneman shoot out solos that are pretty much a complete jumble of random notes, and simple overly used riffs as fast as possible.      To start the album you get the song Angel of Death which gets going really quickly. Once Tom Araya opens his mouth you swear he has one of the worst voices in rock history just hacking out barely comprehensible or incomprehensible lyrics as fast as possible with no depth or power at all. The lyrics that you do here aren't evil or scary, they make you laugh. As a Jew all I found was (when I read the lyrics because u can barely understand them)it was actually funny with sad lines like \\"slow death, immense decay\\" (no good verses just commas of horrific images) only showed how bad lyrical songwriters these guys are. Piece by Piece is even worse and the album pretty much continues sounding exactly the same (minorly different riffs occasionally every here and there but all the same incomprehensible vocals and song structure). The beginning of Jesus Saves offers promise, but the song quickly turns into more of the same old garbage quickly once araya opens his mouth and the rest of the band goes back to their style they were using on the rest of the album. Postmortem offers a nice little opening riff, but its overused and the song never becomes anything worthwile other than same old extreme punk (more that than metal actually as the entire song structures are punk influenced), and the same goes for raining blood.      In the end this album is full of untalented clowns who cant play their instruments trying to sound scary and it comes off flat. Theres almost no variety in the songs, and Kerry King and Hanneman are so overrated its horrible (they're a chaotic mess), and Tom Araya's bass is average and his voice is MISERABLE! Don't buy this piece of junk which sounds like a couple of 14 yr olds in their garage screaming and playing lame riffs with random sloppy solos everywhere and trying to be scary but sounding pathetic. Seriously, a Harley reving up its engine makes better riffs than the overly-repetitive riffs (with one or two exceptions but even those are overplayed and not very complex or great) than hanneman and king. Want good thrash? buy Megadeth's \\"rust in peace\\" (and compare Dave Mustaine and Freedmans guitar to these \\"professionals\\"). want good oldschool metal? Then pick up any 80s Maiden CD or Judas Priest's \\"Stained Class,\\"Screaming for Vengeance,\\" or \\"Painkiller\\" but skip this unless you love wasting your money on 3rd rate bands who aren't as good as the ones mentioned above. Oh yea, the albums really short too, only around 30 mins, which is sad because you have to pay full price for it so that makes it even worse. And was this one of the most influential albums of all time. Not really, it did spawn a couple of even sadder bands (I know its hard to believe) like Cannibal Corpse and Napalm death and some other bad death metal bands, but it hardly changed metal in the long run.

I usually get tired of music rather quickly, but I bought this CD on day one and it has still not left my CD player.  Highly recommended, this is by far the best CD to come out this year.

0393312836|4.0|Don't take this fine novel too seriously. Yes, there's a statement here about free will and the price society must pay for its preservation, but I believe the funny parts were not meant to escape as many readers as they do. There were times when I was reading this story of a violent teenager (much younger than he was in the film version) where I laughed till my sides ached. I know devotees will see that as sacrilege, but it's also just plain true and if you miss the laughs in here, you're missing the best part.<br /><br />A Clockwork Orange is about Alex DeLarge, his teenaged gang of \\"droogs\\" and their sordid misadventures in England a generation or two hence. Alex and his cohorts dress like characters straight out of a comic book, talk to one another in Slavic-flavored \\"nadsat speak\\" an invented, brutal dialect, and imbibe psychotropic-laced milk before proceeding on nightly raids into their dilapidated city. In among the descriptions of turf wars, assaults, robberies, vandalism, rape, and eventually cold-blooded murder, Alex tells us of his keen love of classical music, which he appreciates to...er, \\"auto-erotic\\" heights. Alex is intelligent, driven, shows strong leadership skills, and one gets the sense that in another age or slightly different background he might have made something of promising young Tory spouting \\"Britannia Forever!\\" while wrapping himself in the Union Jack. But not in his rusting era of post-Imperial decomposition.<br /><br />Eventually Alex's crime spree goes too far and he is sent to prison for slaying a woman in her home. In the overcrowded prison, Alex survives and in a manner even thrives, and in the course of serving his time, he is befriended by an earnestly good man, the hard-drinking, true believing chaplain, whom Alex uses to his advantage. It is during this period that Alex learns of a psychological treatment being proposed as a means of solving Britain's horrific crime problems. It involves a sort of brainwashing whereby the recipient can no longer of his own free will choose to undertake an act of violence upon any other living creature. Alex volunteers to be the first to undergo this course of experimentation, and is rendered harmless but somewhat pathetically neutered in his capacity or act on his own volition. It is the consequences of this treatment and the effects it has on Alex's life that provides the final portion of this brilliantly inventive piece of fiction.<br /><br />This is a novel divided into three sections of seven chapters each, highlighting author Burgess' fondness for numerology. Until recently, most readers in the United States read a version that conformed more to the legendary Stanley Kubrick film that ended with Alex \\"cured\\" and once more set free on society. The novel as originally written and now restored goes one step further and projects several years into Alex's future, wherein he outgrows violence and consciously elects to become a law-abiding citizen, an exercise in free will accomplishing what the harsh chemical treatments during his incarceration could not.<br /><br />A Clockwork Orange is a worthy book that rewards with humor and thoughtful prose.er of his own free will choose to undertake an act of violence upon any other living creature. Alex volunteers to be the first to undergo this course of experimentation, and is rendered harmless but somewhat pathetically neutered in his capacity or act on his own volition. It is the consequences of this treatment and the effects it has on Alex's life that provides the final portion of this brilliantly inventive piece of fiction.    This is a novel divided into three sections of seven chapters each, highlighting author Burgess' fondness for numerology. Until recently, most readers in the United States read a version that conformed more to the legendary Stanley Kubrick film that ended with Alex \\"cured\\" and once more set free on society. The novel as originally written and now restored goes one step further and projects several years into Alex's future, wherein he outgrows violence and consciously elects to become a law-abiding citizen, an exercise in free will accomplishing what the harsh chemical treatments during his incarceration could not.    A Clockwork Orange is a worthy book that rewards with humor and thoughtful prose.

Blackout 9.5/10<br />A rather bizarre song to follow something as loud and powerful as Hysteria.  Blackout instead is beautiful and quiet.  But don't let that deter you, the words are powerful and it's one of those songs that grow on you.<br /><br />10. Butterflies and Hurricanes 9.5/10<br />Powerful but Classical.  Begins soft, then gets loud, then goes into a piano interlude and then goes back to being loud and powerful.  A instant classic in my book.<br /><br />11. Small Print 9.3/10<br />A single worthy song that is like Hysteria, which beings loud.  The lyrics are really powerful and it doesn't let up toward the end.  Great song but doesn't sound as strong and powerful as Hysteria<br /><br />12.  Endlessly 8.5/10<br />A beautiful melodramatic song.  Though it has good lyrics, it's not as flowing as say Blackout thus the lower score.<br /><br />13. Thoughts of a Dying Atheist 5/10<br />The worst song on the album, the guitar is good but not great, the lyrics are unoriginal and repetitive.  But that's just my opinion, really depends on your taste.<br /><br />14. Ruled by Secrecy 9.1/10<br />A creepy song to end the wonderful Album though not as beautiful as Blackout.  It still captures the aquired taste title as it's highly anti-Hysteria though not a bad thing, because I like both styles.9. The Cooger & Dark's Pandemonium Shadow Show arrives with its' siren song of youth, beauty and dreams regained.  This siren song is played for each one of the people in Green Town, Illinois.  The boys soon learn that the carnival destroys every life it touches.  Soon they are on the run left up to Mr. Halloway to come to the rescue.<br /><br />I don't want to give away too much of the book but the idea of temptation's siren song played to everyone presents an interesting theme.  Even when the carnival is gone...is it really gone...or is it just gone from Jim, Will and Mr. Halloway?  Have they learned how to deal with its' song?  Will it return again in another Autumn?  Is it in reality always with us? 1400032717|5.0|Mark Haddon would deserve great credit for even attempting this novel; how much more so for making it work so elegantly.  The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time tells the tale that beginning with the dog in a middle class English neighborhood through the eyes and in the voice of a high functioning autistic boy who wants to know what happened.  Such a story might fail on many points, becoming saccharine, the author lapsing in the voice of the narrator, or even taking the story in some unreal direction.  Haddon avoids all these pitfalls delivering instead a poignant and entertaining tale. <br /> <br />Most interesting of all, Haddon does a wonderful job at brining the narrator alive and making the reader understand his unique condition.  On matters of human emotion, the reader recognizes things long before the autistic narrator.  At the same time, avoiding conventions that would portray the protagonist as weak, simple, or stupid, Haddon creates someone we respect for his problem solving ability.  Indeed, the narrator often solves mysteries long before the reader, but in ways that remain both believable and credible.  Haddon further deftly gives us a window into his thought process and makes us feel just how alien our world can be to someone who does not understand emotional nuance.   <br /> <br />With its careful prose and rich story, readers will surely appreciate Mr. Haddon's considerable gifts.  Highly recommended. <br />
B0007Y08IS|2.0|This movie suffers from a one-two punch of ineffective writing and uninteresting puppeteering. It's a parody of action movies, played in a straightforward way. Let's face it, I'm not going to empathize with these nondescript pieces of plastic. It's just not that clever. Even as marionettes go, these were badly designed and badly operated. They can work in a 22 minute TV show with characters we care about, but not when stretched into a 98 minute movie with puppets we don't care about.<br /><br />The South Park guys employed some worn out topics and a bad medium when they made this movie. Macy is underused in his role as the admiral, the commander in chief at NUMA who dishes out Pitt's assignments. Many wished that the Allman Bros remained true to jam band status like the previous \\"AB at Fillmore East\\" and \\"Eat a Peach,\\" but I believe is was just a part of their evolution to become a tighter band, with less improvisation, and with better writing capabilities.  Live, they were unparalleled.  These early efforts became the hallmarks of their career which has more or less survived to this day.<br /><br />Sadly, the AB band has lost too many of their original players to death or attrition, and they are still a good band, just not to their former abilities.  There will never be another Duane Allman who could play lead and slide like he could.  Maybe there will, but it will be a long wait for the same style that he played.

B00065MDRW|5.0|This album gains enough popularity by being known as the start of Progressive rock. This may or may not be true, but it sure got the progressive rock message to many people very early on. \\"21st Century Schizoid Man\\" is a very hard driven jazz/rock fusion along with Greg Lake's almost insane tone in the lyrics. The instrument passage is very fast and tight; it was played very well. The mood changes to the mellow \\"I Talk to the Wind\\", which is actually the song that got me into Crimson. The flute along with the soft ride cymbal makes the song flow beautifully, with Greg Lake once again diving into the vocals to make them fit perfect to the song. Next is \\"Epitaph\\", which is a very emotional driven songs with very meaningful lyrics. Here is an example, \\"Knowledge is a deadly friend/When no one sets the rules/The fate of all Mankind I see/is in the hands of fools.\\" The next song is \\"Moonchild\\" which is the most beautiful song on the album. It contains the most poetic lyrics on the album. Lastly, \\"In the Court of the Crimson King\\" brings us to the close of the album. It has a folk flavor between the choruses to mellow the mood until the guitars and orchestration take over. <br />    This is an absolutely flawless album and should be in everyone's music collection, regardless if you like progressive rock or not. Recommended with Yes' \\"Close to the Edge\\".
B000AADYYO|4.0|This Swedish quintet have always done their type of metal perfectly: balancing beauty and brutality. 2002's \\"Deliverance\\" was arguably their heaviest album, whereas its sister album, 2003's \\"Damnation,\\" was completely acoustic. \\"Damnation\\" was very pretty, but it only had one mood; it lacked Opeth's famous rapid tempo changes and breakdowns. In that sense, \\"Ghost Reveries\\" is much more of a traditional Opeth album, because it's full of bone crushing breakdowns (and long songs, too; the songs on this record are, on average, over eight minutes in length.) But that's not saying \\"Ghost Reveries\\" is predictable, because even though you know there are going to be tempo changes and breakdowns in about every song, you just don't know when they're going to happen.<br /><br />There's a drawback to a traditional Opeth album like this: it sounds a little too familiar. Fortunately, however, even though it has many similarities to past Opeth C.D.'s, (i.e. \\"My Arms, Your Hearse\\"), \\"Ghost Reveries\\" isn't exactly a rehash of a past album. In addition to having a little bit more (and improved) melody, Opeth hired their first ever keyboardist (Per Wiberg) to play on such songs as \\"The Baying of the Hounds.\\" Plus, track four, \\"Atonement,\\" features Middle Eastern drumming.<br /><br />\\"Ghost of Perdition\\" smoothly switches back and forth from power chords and heavy, guttural bellows and light, eloquent strumming. This isn't a bad song, but it doesn't present anything new for Opeth.<br />\\"The Baying of the Hounds\\" finds vocalist Mikael Akerfeldt laying down death metal growls over a skipping rhythm. The song slows down and a couple of cool piano keys (by Per) make an entrance, but the beat speeds back up, and a guitar solo is also tossed in near the end.<br />\\"Beneath the Mire\\" begins with (what sounds like) an organ playing between the guitarists' crunchy riffs. The organ stops, but the guitarists continue playing over a some buzzing bass riffs. The end of this song sort of blends in with the next song, track four.<br />\\"Atonement\\" is a personal favorite because it's just so darn pretty. Opeth make an innovative use of the Middle Eastern drums (which are played by hand), and Mikael's vocals are dreary. There is some electric guitar playing in this song, but it's about half as aggressive and loud as usual. Finally, the keyboardist again enters the mix near the end.<br />\\"Reverie/Harlequin Forest\\" begins with light guitar playing, but it fades out less than a second after it began. There are some chunky riffs near the end of this song, and (even though the music is pretty heavy) Mikael uses his clean, calm voice to carry the tune well and make it somewhat melodic. Unfortunately, this song doesn't deviate from Opeth's patented soft-hard-soft-hard song structure.<br />\\"Hours of Wealth\\" has more acoustic guitars and proper singing which is almost soulful at times. This song is entirely acoustic, and while it isn't as pretty as \\"Atonement,\\" it does have a nice, relaxed guitar solo.<br />\\"The Grand Conjuration\\" works up a thrashing groove, with more bobbing, punching riffs.<br />\\"Isolation Years\\" is another very peaceful acoustic track. The instruments and the vocals are very graceful and dreamy, making the listener feel like they're on a cloud.<br /><br />Opeth have pretty much always used the same formula: death metal alongside pretty, alternative rock. But Opeth do this formula so well that their music doesn't sound stale or recycled. And Opeth have had great success with this formula, so if it ain't broken, why fix it?<br /><br />In conclusion, these songs could use a few more distinguishing features, but this album definitely sounds great. It's still a worthy, four star album which deserves the attention of all metalheads. If you're an Opeth fanatic, this album is a must, and if you're new to them, this is a good place to start.our.  \\"Atonement\\" is a personal favorite because it's just so darn pretty. Opeth make an innovative use of the Middle Eastern drums (which are played by hand), and Mikael's vocals are dreary. There is some electric guitar playing in this song, but it's about half as aggressive and loud as usual. Finally, the keyboardist again enters the mix near the end.  \\"Reverie/Harlequin Forest\\" begins with light guitar playing, but it fades out less than a second after it began. There are some chunky riffs near the end of this song, and (even though the music is pretty heavy) Mikael uses his clean, calm voice to carry the tune well and make it somewhat melodic. Unfortunately, this song doesn't deviate from Opeth's patented soft-hard-soft-hard song structure.  \\"Hours of Wealth\\" has more acoustic guitars and proper singing which is almost soulful at times. This song is entirely acoustic, and while it isn't as pretty as \\"Atonement,\\" it does have a nice, relaxed guitar solo.  \\"The Grand Conjuration\\" works up a thrashing groove, with more bobbing, punching riffs.  \\"Isolation Years\\" is another very peaceful acoustic track. The instruments and the vocals are very graceful and dreamy, making the listener feel like they're on a cloud.    Opeth have pretty much always used the same formula: death metal alongside pretty, alternative rock. But Opeth do this formula so well that their music doesn't sound stale or recycled. And Opeth have had great success with this formula, so if it ain't broken, why fix it?     In conclusion, these songs could use a few more distinguishing features, but this album definitely sounds great. It's still a worthy, four star album which deserves the attention of all metalheads. If you're an Opeth fanatic, this album is a must, and if you're new to them, this is a good place to start.
0061015725|5.0|Science Fiction is most often a genre characterized by either plotlines taking place in the far future with amazing technology, or present day events with hidden discoveries and advancements. Michael Crichton takes the genre in a unique and genius direction with Prey. He uses extreme detail to present certain realities that come together to create something that could logically exist but those realities are as or more amazing or horrific than science fiction.  <br /> <br />Prey is a tale of corporate greed and ignorance. While the main character, Jack, already proved he had strength against his company's instability, his wife is starting to care more and more about her work and as a result she loses interest in her family. Jack then refuses to give up the faith he holds in his wife but he still must satisfy his curiosity, so he accepts a job that will put him in direct contact with her and her coworkers. Thus is the magic of Crichton's reality making you believe in the main character's conviction and what he will do later on in the story. <br /> <br />Because of its logic and emotion, Prey is a story that will work for almost anyone with any interest in science fiction and could potentially draw in those who are unsure about the genre. If there is any weakness in this book, it is how repetitive the descriptions of the technology start to feel if you already understand the basic premise. Otherwise the detail is helpful in understanding the story. <br /> <br />With its detailed and logical plot, Prey is a very intense read as Crichton does an excellent job of generating curiosity and emotion in the reader that coincides with the main character's struggle. For an example of how great Crichton's writing skill is, Prey is among the best. <br />  <br />
0446607274|4.0|I downloaded this detective procedural in electronic format and read it on my Palm during my commute to work.  Better than the usual, routine story about a murder, this novel focuses on the tensions between the LAPD and the people of Los Angeles in the wake of the Rodney King incident.  It's an entertaining read with substance, as the plot touches on the racial biases and political issues that play an often unacknowledged role in law enforcement in a contemporary urban environment.<br /><br />I've found e-books to be economical, as they are often priced several dollars less than a mass market paperback, and they can be easily moved to an external storage device after I'm done reading them on my handheld.  And since I have to carry my Palm around with me everyday in order to access my calendar and contacts files, an electronic book eliminates the need to carry printed reading material, and thus reduces the weight in my shoulder bag.<br /><br />Michael Connelly's books are particularly appropriate for the handheld medium because they are plot-driven page-turners that don't require me to check footnotes or an index.  I'm not sure I'd be equally enthusiastic about using the electronic format for a text book or research report.

B0009Y336A|5.0|I was lucky enough to hear the album a number of times before its release in the States.<br /><br />I have been a massive fan of this band since the release of I Should Coco and few have delivered with each release as Supergrass.  Supergrass have slowly inched away from their more aggressive debut and this album shows a band in full maturation without becoming stodgy.  Every track is outstanding and the care in production is obvious.  I doubt this album will give them the attention and respect they deserve, however, for those who take a chance, they will be richly rewarded and immediately want the rest of their catalog. While the jury is still out on Coldplay, not even Radiohead among the others mentioned have been able to consistently release one strong album after another.  This has not been the case with Supergrass.<br /><br />Tales Of Endurance (Parts 4, 5 & 6) kicks the album off with a mellow entrance giving way to a rollicking exit.  It serves as a sample of what is to come.  Its hard for a band to mature while keeping the songwriting true to their roots and this has always been a strength Supergrass had in spades.  The best tracks would probably be St. Petersburg, Roxy and Low C.  They were blamed for being a bit over the top on their second release In It For The Money but most felt it was because they sounded a bit too overproduced.  I disagreed with that but could understand the sentiment.  This is definitely not true with this release.  The soundscape present on this release feels very organic and warm, it almost feels like your listening to it on vinyl.  Anyone who ever had a vinyl collection should catch what I mean by that.  There are horns, strings and rich texture to all of the songs and yet they don't forget to rock out here and there as well.<br /><br />If you love great Pop Rock that simultaneously doesn't take itself too seriously yet reaches for the stars then this album is for you.  After ten years I'm convinced that the only thing that can stop this band would be an apathetic public that ends their ability to release more music. 192076920X|1.0|I am consistently amazed by the rave reviews for this overlong, tedious and egocentric book. Gregory David Roberts broke out of jail and spent 8 years in India- and it seems he spent most of that time watching Bollywood movies and imagining himself as one of their musclebound superheroes. <br /> <br />Anyone familiar with Hindi cinema staples will recognize all of the usual ingredients here- a tough anti-hero with one foot in the slums and the other in the glitzy underworld of organized crime; the mysterious heroine with a secret life; the over the top action scenes; the bullet riddled character who returns from the grave in the final act; a character who turns out to have an evil twin and the sudden surge of mother love that sets the anti-hero on the road to righteousness. Heck, he even writes  in scenes in which characters spontaneously burst into song.  <br /> <br />The same kind of stuff can be consumed on the screen in an hour or two, without having to wade through a massive missive the size of an average edition of the Bible. <br /> <br />Not only does Roberts expect readers to take this recycled Bolly-waffle as an original story, but he also wants us to swallow it as an autobiography.  <br /> <br />The self egrandising tone is pretty hard to take- there are repeated descriptions of himself as both a \\"hard, muscled tough man\\" and a \\"sensitive intellectual activist\\". In addition to rescuing countless helpless slum dwellers, becoming a doctor, battling Rambo style in Afghanistan, surviving a prison tourture sequence so elaborate it seems lifted from \\"The Passion of the Christ\\", saving white babes from sexual slavery, kung fu fighting a pack of wild dogs and becoming a kind of Bombay Don Corleone, Roberts also finds time to slip \\"the meaning of life\\" ( a kind of masala mix of Hinduism and Stephen Hawkings) into a single chapter. <br /> <br />This book is dreadful, and the worst thing is that some reveiwers have touted it as a great book about India. This is an Indian story in as much as Tarzan was a great African story or \\"Dances with Wolves' was a history of the Sioux Nation. India, and Indians are pretty much window dressing to Roberts boy's own adventure here. <br /> <br />If you want to read about India, read some Indian authors like Raj Khamal Jha or Amitav Ghosh.. If you are interested in a foreigners experience of Asian cultures, check out David Mitchell... but if you want trash like Shantaram, rent a copy of Bollywood cheese like Mission: Kashmir, it will waste a lot less time than this...

2253005274|4.0|I read this book back in high school because I was intrigued by the title (\\"The Wanderer\\"). I enjoyed it at the time, and through the years I always remembered it as one that really resonated with my gloomy adolescent mind.<br /><br />Feeling nostalgic recently, I located a used copy and read it again, trying to recapture whatever it was that had engaged me so many years before. It was interesting to experience the same story from a more seasoned perspective in life. It was not as deep as it had once seemed to me in youth, and yet I noticed and understood many nuances and details that had been opaque to my teenage mind.  In a way this parallels the story in the novel.  Youth imagines what maturity never sees, and maturity knows what youth never imagined.<br /><br />The edition I bought included a short biography of the author, who was killed in WWI - this was his only book. It was interesting that the story of the lost love was based on real events in Alain Fournier's short life. It is a glimpse into just one young life that was snuffed out by war, all future promise never to be revealed. As such, it is a story which is nearly as wistful and sad as the novel itself. Just as one wonders \\"what could have been\\" if Meaulnes got the girl, so we wonder what other novels Fournier might have gone on to write, had he not been buried beneath the sod of Europe.

B00000G3I2|4.0|A group of 1960s college idealists and friends meet one weekend in the early '80s after the death of another in the group. By now most of them have chucked those old ideals and are into making money. They talk a lot, about the old days and the new, and we see how much their lives have changed - none for the better, really. William Hurt is excellent as the cynic of the group, a wounded Vietnam vet now incapable of having sex. There are some great lines here in the dialogue, even though many have a cutesy-clever ring to them, with a drumroll delivery. It's kind of stagey and somewhat pretentious, but for anyone who's been there and can relate to the overall message it's never a bore to watch. The Motown music track, heard prominently throughut the movie, for many is a huge plus; it sort of worked against the movie for me. Many of the actors  springboarded from here to star status: Hurt, Jeff Goldblum, Glenn Close, and Kevin Kline in particular. Worth a watch.

B00006ADG8|5.0|A very fine adaptation of Herman Melville's story of morality and the law aboard an English man-of-war in 1797. Peter Ustinov is Captain Vere, who believes the code of his office is the only one to live by, which makes no room for human judgment or conscience. Terence Stamp is the naive, innocent, Christ-like Budd, who kills the sadistic master-at-arms Robert Ryan out of self-defense when his stammer prevents him from talking. Melvyn Douglas is the self-loathing Claggart. Everyone is superb, and the script is faithful to the original. There is much to ponder about here, and repeated viewings only add to the enjoyment and inner searching. Highly recommended.

B000A3DFZE|1.0|I really hate to give this record only one star. Like one reviewer just said, eric was coming off the cream reunion and a really good Robert Johnson record and tour, and maybe we were expecting a corner turn in his somewhat laid back studio attempts over the last few years (reptile, pilgrim). This record makes those seem energetic. Lets face it. Eric is a great talent, but people should know where their strenghts lie. Songwriting was never a real strong suit for him. We all know that his strenght lies in his guitar and in his love for the blues. None of these are present on this disc. His tales of domesticity in these tunes are almost downright depressing. Anyway, according to my inventory.  <br />THE FOLLOWING MOVIES / COMPANY HAVE FAILED TO PRODUCE ANAMORPHIC OR 16X9 WIDESCREEN and I hope that these company will release them in the near future so that we can enjoy them on our TVs.  <br /> <br />MGM:  <br /> <br />Runaway Train  <br />Graduate  <br />No Way Out  <br />Prizzi's Honor  <br />FX  <br />Shallow Grave  <br />Thief  <br />House Of Games  <br />Dead Man Walking  <br />Misery  <br />The Eye Of The Needle  <br />Overboard  <br /> <br />PARAMOUNT:  <br /> <br />Private Parts  <br />48 Hrs  <br />Coming To America  <br />Primal Fear  <br />The Ghost And The Darkness  <br />Breakdown  <br /> <br />UNIVERSAL:  <br /> <br />Day Of The Jackal  <br />Psycho (AVAILABLE IN THE RECENT HITCHCOCK'S BOXSET AS ANAMORPHIC)  <br />Vertigo (AVAILABLE IN THE RECENT HITCHCOCK'S BOXSET AS ANAMORPHIC)  <br />The Game  <br /> <br />FOX:  <br /> <br />Abyss (I WAS SHOCKED TO LEARN THAT MY 2-DISC IS NOT ANAMORPHIC, NOR IS THE LATEST DIGIPACK EDITION)  <br />Raising Arizona  <br />The Edge  <br />Great Expectations  <br />Rising Sun  <br />The Ref  <br />Romancing The Stone  <br />The Jewel Of The Nile  <br /> <br />ARTISAN:  <br /> <br />House Of The Spirits  <br />The Last Seduction  <br />The Last Emperor  <br />The Eagle Has Landed  <br />Bound  <br /><br />PS: PLEASE ARTISAN, INSTEAD OF RELEASING 'BASIC INSTINCT' FOR THE 4TH TIME, WHICH MOST HAVE ALMOST THE SAME SPECIFICATIONS, CONSIDER RELEASING SOME MORE INTERESTING MOVIES WITH PROPER ATTENTION SUCH AS THOSE MENTIONED ABOVE.  <br /> <br />TOUCHSTONE / WALT DISNEY:  <br /> <br />Ransom  <br />What About Bob?  <br /> <br />PS: IT IS A GREAT NEWS THAT TOUCHSTONE ARE RELEASING 'ENEMY OF THE STATE', CRIMSON TIDE' AND 'CON AIR' IN EXTENDED UNRATED EDITIONS ON MAY 16. B000002JSP|4.0|This seems to be a love it/hate it album. Those who hate it complain of the synths and keyboards, but LZ used Jones' keyboard talents throughout their career - those weren't flutes on \\"Stairway to Heaven\\". Synths weren't used earlier simply because the only ones available then were RCA Labs wall-o'-knobs Moogs with their LAN wiring-closet of patch cords and drifting osc's. But there always were plenty of mellotrons and clavinets. <br /> <br />Another reason for the different sound of this album, if I recall my \\"Hammer of the Gods\\" correctly, is that Page was, at the time...how to put this delicately...more consistantly 'in the arms of Morpheus' is how the book phrases it. Someone had to step in and fill the gap, and that someone was John Paul Jones, who always had a lot more creative input than he's been given credit. <br /> <br />In the Evening - Classic, loud, mid-tempo LZ, although Jones plays a keyboard rhythm instead of Page recording a 4th or 5th guitar track. And how does Page make his guitar sound like a motorcycle starting up? <br /> <br />Southbound Suarez - who can resist its stomping honky-tonk pulse and Page's counterpoint guitar slide? It's almost as an endurance song as \\"Rock & Roll\\". <br /> <br />Fool in the Rain - it's hard to review this song and not penalize it because of its being one of only three LZ songs classic rock stations play anymore, and therefore is a bit tiresome. Except for an electronically-doubled solo, what few guitars there are are buried behind the piano in the mix. But, hey - Plant is actually singing a melody. The song dissolves into an odd off-the-wall samba in the middle; Bonham must have just been sent some rotos he wanted to play with. <br /> <br />Hot Dog - Hillbilly Led Zepplin rebel-rock. But it's better than its reputation, and if taken with a grain of humor, it's a lot of fun. LZ  wasn't always just about the torment and depression of \\"Dazed and Confused\\" or \\"I Can't Quit You\\". <br /> <br />Carouselambra - in the the original CD release this song's levels were down about 1/3; it almost sounded like a different album. The remastered CD punches it up and brightens it considerably, although I still had to go online to figure out what Plant was saying. Page's guitars yield the spotlight to Jones' synth playing and typical virtuoso bass lines. Bonham drumming is more restrained than some of the other 10.5-minute studio-jam sessions like \\"In My Time of Dying\\" and \\"Nobody's Fault But Mine\\". But a restrained Bonham is twice the drummer of anybody in the business today, except for Neil Peart or Mike Portnoy. \\"Carouselambra\\" twists and morphs though several mood changes and slowly fades out like it's the last song on the album... <br /> <br />All My Love - My least favorite on the album, although I am well aware of its subject. It's not bad, but something had to be the least. And it's not helped by being another of the only three Led Zeppelin Songs That Classic Rock Stations Ever, Ever Play. Jones' keyboards and Page's single (!) rhythm guitar track set the mood, and Jones' nice solo gives the song an Eastern flavor you never knew was there. <br /> <br />I'm Gonna Crawl - Starts out with another fluffy string synth intro, then Bonham's big bluesy bass drum kicks in and you know this is going to be LZ classic cry-in-your-beer woman-done-left-me wrencher. Nobody does it better.

B0009SS00A|2.0|I've been in the IT field for over 20 years, and cannot read a book or watch a movie or TV show that has anything to do with computers as its central theme. No one ever gets it right, and I'm not talking small details that just the bit-counters might see. I'm talking about the classic eye-rollers like the \\"I know this - it's UNIX!\\" line in Jurassic Park I, the whole concept of a podunk little Apple laptop infecting an alien armada in \\"Independence Day\\" (as though the aliens got here by pedalling), up to the standard Hollywood corndoggery of beeping character displays, big walls of blinky lights, and credit-thrashing, Internet-savvy children.    But 'The DaVinci Code' and 'Angels and Demons' were fun enough reads - historical and geographical romps with a few stretched but interesting concepts and conclusions. So against my normally better judgement, I tried Digital Fortress...    So you're not in a computer-related field - would the book stand on its story? Not really. Some of the concepts required a suspension of disbelief along the scope of the latest superhero flavor-of-the-month movie. Not good if you want a book grounded in reality - in fantasy, where the rules of the world are made up, where's the suspense? You just \\"make up\\" a resolution, and then roll credits.. There was also a great deal of \\"Quick! To the Bat Cave!\\"-type urgent dashing about, characters whose lives were in danger whom I didn't care about, and a long d----r----a-----w----n-out ending where the super-villain stumps shiny, pointy-headed, over-achieving, heavily-degreed intellectuals with a question anybody remotely familiar with WWII would know. Not only do they not know the answer, they don't even understand the question. Until, of course, it's convenient for the plot that they finally and breathlessly do.    Dan Brown could do better. Dan Brown HAS done better.

B000000OQF|5.0|Guns N' Roses debut Appetite For Destruction is one of the greatest albums in rock history, rivaling, maybe eclipsing, the best music of Zeppelin, Aerosmith, even the Stones. Rising out of the L.A. metal glam scene of the mid-eighties they wrote songs that dealt with drug addiction, paranoia, urban decay, explicit sex, and salvation. Popular music in the eighties was slick, pre-packaged, heavily produced, relying more on image than musical talent. What sounded so fresh about G N' R was that they could actually play their instruments. The music was genuine and raged with passion and ferocity. While the band pulled no punches exposing the depravity of Hollywood street life they also embraced tenderness and idealism. The music bangs, crashes, and boogies with a subversive punk rock attitude. Appetite's best tracks 'Welcolme To The Jungle', Paradise City' or 'Sweet Child O' Mine' are classic arena rock anthems. Millions of teenagers identified with Axl Rose as he railed against a society he viewed as corrupt and out to exploit him. Slash's elegaic solos soar over Izzy Stradlin's tough R&B inflected riffing. And the devil mare care rhythm section of Duff McCagen and Steven Adler achieve a perfect balance between remaining tight but loose. If your a fan of hard rock your collection isn't complete without a copy of Appetite.

Not really a protest album, but not really Kerplunk, the album tells the tale of the Jesus of Suburbia. It opens with American Idiot, a song about how the American probaganda is changing everyone and anyone and how confusion if formed in America. Overall, a good energetic track. The bridge of the song is very powerfull and full of meaning. I'm going to go a little offtopic here on the review and discuss the video a little bit. One, it's not really a protest video. It shows that some kids, who think they're doing the right thing by joining the military are dying before living there lives. Overall, a good song. After that is Homecoming. The second epic, I just love this song. Espically Part Three: Nobody Likes You. After the epic is Whatshername, which is a excellent closer to the album and story behind American Idiot.

B000AP04MO|3.0|Folks who've seen any movie featuring either Albert Finney or Audrey Hepburn are likely to be sold on Two For The Road before it starts. Sweetening the promise is Stanley Donen in the director's chair, having previously directed Hepburn in 1963's wildly intriguing and stylish CHARADE. Donen appears to be trading on viewers' appreciation for CHARADE when he opens this film with another animated, 60's/Austin Powers-style title sequence, but that's the last similarity - until you start to notice that a fair amount of time is ticking by...    We are introduced to Finney and Hepburn as a bored, wealthy couple waiting to board an air ferry over the English channel. Finney's Mark Wallace, a successful architect, does not conceal his disenchantment with his wife and she does not conceal her frustration with him. The fading relationship is not a new literary device, and the dullened question of \\"how did we get here\\" doesn't pave a way for break-through cinema, so the film takes rather a gamble by launching into a 90-minute flashback to tell us the whole, sprawling story of this couple - before it's gotten us to care about them.    Nonetheless, average moviegoer patience should be enough to keep one focused long enough to notice the charm and the edginess of these characters, whetting our appetite for the ongoing sass of courtship. As a relationship unfurls, we are taken on road trips through Europe, to quaint bed-and-breakfasts in the French countryside, to wealthy people's estates - these elements alone tend to captivate American audiences even without regard to the dyad of titanic thespian talent in the foreground. But beware Americans, we are portrayed most unflatteringly in the personages of Howard and Cathy Manchester, a shamelessly modern couple (played with sheer mastery by William Daniels and Eleanor Bron) with whom Finney and Hepburn find themselves sharing an overly regimented road trip (to Howard's timekeeper objections to leaving \\"the main road\\", Finney rants, \\"Ishould warn you Howard, before we get to Athens, that the Acropolis is OFF THE MAIN ROAD\\").    Such satisfying jabs, and the more traditionally British dry wit, occur just often enough to sustain our interest in this picture, but oftentimes their occurrence reminds us that our interest needed refreshing.    All-in-all, this film gives us a nice dose of face-time with two of the most talented, enchanting actors in movie history, a leisurely dawdle through European countryside, and a little wink back in time to when America and Great Britain were embarking on something of a love affair of their own.    Like that affair, this one can be engaging, refreshing, boring, eye-opening, forced, unfounded, tiring, and worthwhile.
B00000J7JO|5.0|The Chili's produce another stunning album with the return of guitarest john Frusciante. I like most rock bands from the nineties, such as Nirvana, Smashing Pumpkins, Jane's Adiction, sound garden etc...., but the Chili Peppers just leave them standing in the past. Their music is individual, blending raw emotion with funky guitar riffs. And if this isn't enough to sway your views they are made all the more deserving by the death of their first guitarist, Hillel Slovak, and they still mannaged to come back stronger and create some on the most original and inventive music ever.  <br />The Red Hot Chili Peppers will always be remembered as one of the most entertaining bands ever, rivaling The Beatles and Jimi Hendrix. <br />

B000002H2H|5.0|The second album got out in 1984, the first album with Kirk Hammett that joined after Dave Mustaine was kicked out, although he had a part of this album in two of the songs. This was actually my first introduction to real metal (not nu-metal, metalcore or hair-metal), and pretty much like The Wickerman this instantly became my favorite album, it's no longer but it certainly ranks in my top 20 favorite albums. This is how metal should sound like. Blazing solos, vocals, energy, it slows down only for one song (Fade to Black).    Song Ratings:    Fight Fire With Fire (9/10): Good start-off. Not as great as 'Battery', 'Blackened' and 'Enter Sandman', but still great. It took time to grow on my but now I like it.    Ride the Lightning (20/10): Call me crazy but this is my all time fav 'Tallica song. IMO this song gets far too little credit since I rarely hear people praise song. The lyrics are about someone who is going to be executed and the solo is probably the best I've heard from the band.    For Whom The Bell Tolls (10/10): Very slow but still heavy, It is one of few Metallica's songs without solo: This and all the songs on St Anger.    Fade to Black (10/10): Metallica's first ballad, powerful lyrics about suicide, I can play it on my guitar. And the solo in the end is incredible.    Trapped Under Ice (10/10): Very underrated. People tend to diss this song for some reason. Why? I don't know. Every solo before the verses is killer and the chorus is great.    Escape (8/10): Its the weakest on the album, but not bad as people say. You may ask why, the solo is kinda sloppy. However anything else is great, I especially like the siren in the end.    reeping Death (10/10): Great lyrics about the Exodus of Egypt.  The solo is one of the best Kirk ever put out. This also used to be my favorite song on the album, it's no longer but it still rocks.    Call of Ktulu (11/10): One of the best instrumentals I ever heard, it goes in the same scales, great riffs and another killer solo. This was also written by Mustaine.    All in all, this one of the best that metal has to offer. If you're a metalhead you must have this.

B0009QTS1M|4.0|I love this movie, and I can almost love this DVD. The 200+minute documentary is amazingly in-depth in many aspects of the film, but is astonishingly deficient in one significant area: CASTING. Features on weapons, costumes, the conception and writing, visual effects are all extraordinarily in-depth on the level of the LOTR EEs, but with the exception of Oliver Reed (who unfortunately passed away during the filming), hardly anything else is mentioned about how the movie was cast. There was hardly or no mention at all about how major actors Russell Crowe, Richard Harris or Joaquin Phoenix were approached about doing this movie, and why they were chosen. In fact, there is no section of this documentary focusing on actors at all (again, except for Oliver Reed).  I think some details were mentioned here and there in the commentary, but it's absence from the main documentary is rather puzzling. It leaves a rather large void in what would have been one of the best documentaries on DVDs I've seen.

I have a very good DVD 5.1 system and I found the sound well balanced, with an empahsis on the music making more than the concert experience. Ambient audience noise is muffled. Good. This ain't Springsteen. <br />From the signature Stravinsky quote through STARSHIP TROOPER, the intensity, humour and passion about this material comes across terrifically, and Steve Howe is an absolute wonder, even if he looks older than God Almighty. Knuckleheads 1/5 his age should play 1/5 as well. And Howe is very much the unsung hero of the history of YES. He plays the works of Peter Banks and Trevor Rabin with the same commitment as though he had been the composer. All of YES's most memorable moments have come courtesy of Howe's fleet command of the classics, jazz and rock and his incredible commitment to his instrument. There has never been a guiatrist quite like him. How could there be? Who else could make musical sense out of the naff lyrics of Jon Anderson? <br />Chris Squier is still looking for a sartorial genie. Hopelessly out of whack with any sense of fashion, he nevertheless commands his bass with authority and still has the choir boy vocal chops to fill out Anderson's still soaring vocals. Yes the key is lower than it used to be, but Anderson still soars where non-eunuchs fear to tread. White seems to be the picture of health and Wakeman looks like he's determined to make rehab work this time. In any case they cover the entire career, and along with the just published triple CD of concert takes, THE WORD IS LIVE, YES delivers a comprehensive review of an astoundingly creative 35 years. it will be interesting to see where they pick up after the brilliant ILLUMINATION CD/DVD of a couple years back. That CD seemed to point to a whole new direction, and given the positively energetic and brilliant SPECTRUM  released by Steve Howe this year, hopefully 2006 will see a new YES release. In any case, silly stage design and all, it is a great concert well filmed and mixed. You should enjoy this one.

The time spent reading this book was delightful in my aspects. Although it took me a long period of time to read \\"Prey,\\" it made my wonder could this really happen to us. For an accidental experiment to go on a rampage, killing everyone who comes into contact with them. Ignoring to stop the experiment before it gets out of hands to save a company from failure. I learned a lot about how far technology has developed over the years. Although this book is a science fiction novel doesn't mean it can't happen. The setting of this book is in modern day California. Us as readers can relate to this book. This book is not only about technology. This book contains similar situations we have at home and in life. The main character, Jack Foreman, was recently fired and taking over position of house mom. While he is at home his wife is working long hours to support the family. Then Jack is getting ideas that his wife is having an affair. On top of all this his two oldest son and daughter can't seem to stop fighting. Also his youngest baby daughter gets a mysterious infection. The writer, Michael Crichton, gives us a familiar setting to get us into the book. Which is a great strength, but he also adds a little history in to the book. History about the evolution of ape developing into man and man developing technology. If you like to wonder how man became man and how it is possible we are still evolving. The weaknesses of this book id very rare. The only thing I can maybe ask for is more suspense. This type of book is for those who love to read survival novels. This book has their share of surprising twists to change the mood of the audience. This type of text I have never read before. I think this book has a similar style to Hatchet by Gary Paulson. This book is probably on of my favorites, right behind Harry Potter. I hope you enjoy the book the way I did and see the power of technology.  <br />

Pi is not content with just one religion, Pi is praticing three religions all at once. His father is the curator of the zoo in Pondicherry, and when he decides to move to Canada the animals come too. The ship crashes in the Pacific ocean and Pi is stuck in a life boat with an orangutang, a hyena, a zebra, and a huge bengal tiger. On his own he creates a special bond with the tiger and learns how to survive by himself. Pi learns how to fish, clean sea water for drinking, and tame the tiger all by himself. It's just Pi, a tiger, and mother nature out in the Pacific Ocean. Mr. Martel does a marvelous job of portraying a boy who is fighting against the elements to survive. All the characters  The positives of this book are well pretty much about everything. Mr. Martel's characters are very dynamic in the sense that they have many different faces and they are always suprising the reader. There were no negatives I could think of. B000003TAR|5.0|In Utero was the follow up to Nirvana's chart topping Nevermind album, which was met with much enthusiasm and just as much animosity by those who considered themselves too punk for them.  It is a phenomenal album.  This is their best work, bar none. <br /> <br />Every song is a jewel, not one song that was just ok or didn't float our boats.  It's more abrasive than \\"Nevermind\\", it was kind of an angry lashing out at all the mainstream attention they had gotten from the last album and were trying to push people away.  But those who heard it were pulled even closer.  From \\"Serve The Servants\\" to \\"All Apologies\\", every song was just as much a glimpse into Kurt's mind as there was a great musical experience.  The faster songs were rowdy and loud, the slower songs were retrospective and moving.  It made you want to smash, lash and claw your way to a new horizon.  And when you made it to the top, you had joy. <br /> <br />When he died, I put this album in the stereo and cried all night until the sun came up.  I felt a thousand stabbing pains, half his, half mine.  Why?  Why?  Why?  I kept asking myself.  He had so much more to give, so much more music to make, and somehow he couldn't go on.  I miss him.  I miss his presence as well as his music.  He ushered in a new era of DIY singer songwriters, something we seem to have lost in music today.

Though I liked the beginning, I didn't become fully engrossed until page 50 and on.<br /><br />The story itself, told by Dr. Watson, Holmes friend and assistant, follows the mysterious death (or murder) of Sir Charles Baskerville.  There is a legend surrounding the Baskervilles, and it tells of a devilish hound which has cursed the family.  Suspiciouns of this tale being true are heightened when peasants report of seeing a hound on the moor and unexplained howlings travel on the wind.  Dr. Mortimer, a friend of the deceased Charles, comes to Holmes asking him to help make sense of the mysterious death and advise him on what to do with the heir to Baskerville Hall, Henry Baskerville, who is arriving from Canada.  Many curious characters and surprising twists befall our protagonists.  I will leave the plot discription at that, for I do not want to spoil anything.<br /><br />This book is a classic and is a very enjoyable read. B00005JNTX|1.0|Remember those ultra-violent \\"CREEP\\"-type horror comix that used to sit beside Superman, Batman, and Spiderman on variety-store racks in the late 60s?  They apparently evolved (DEvolved?) into the \\"Graphic Novel\\"....a modern pic-book format that is simply a more stylishly presented comic book.  Computer-moviemaking has progressed to the point that these gratuitously violent cartoons can be presented onscreen.  SIN CITY is a hyper-stylized, cartoonish film that blends actors--sometimes in ridiculous pancake makeup (a la DICK TRACY)--with a pseudo-film-noir black-and-white/splash-of-single-color \\"look\\" and improbable, ultra-violent special effects.  Sick stuff, with cannibalism, child molestation and murder, and bloody pound-the-head-to-a-pulp violence forming the basis for short, brainless stories of revenge and glorified depravity.  Even Mickey Rourke's grotesque \\"hero\\", in the longest segment of this disjointed, adolescent mess, is supposed to be laudable for his habit of torturing--in blood-spattering detail--all bad guys who get in his way.  The simple-minded moral basis here is that as long as you wear the white hat, any violence you commit against anyone on the \\"opposite side\\" is justified.  A real Republican, reactionary, fascist-WASP point of view.  This movie is gratuitous, occasionally visually arresting (but the style gets old fast), and loaded with disgusting images worthy of those pimple-faced , maladjusted adolescence male punks who used to lurk around the hall lockers in high-school trading joints and cigarettes while plotting to be late for every class.  Don't waste your time.  Even the scrumptious current pop-tart Jessica Alba is poorly displayed....you don't really get the sense that she's there at all.  Maybe it's all that gloom and artificial shadow.  A crappy burp-echo of classic 40s film-noir.  Don't waste your time or money.

0887306101|5.0|This book is genuinely very enlightening. It profiles big--and not so big--named traders/investors who make both consistent and large profits from various markets (futures, stocks, currencies, and commodities.)  <br /> <br />Very importantly this book (and the series) demonstrates that money can be made from a wide variety of trading/investing styles: men who are pure fundamentalists that don't even look at charts to pure technicians and many forms in between are interviewed here. The lesson is that money can be made in various ways and that there are no golden rules to profitability, but rather a slew of solid systems with their own unique collection of mechanical and, usually, intuitive rules. The very important subject of investor psychology is a dominent theme throughout the book. <br /> <br />At the end of chapters and the end of the book the author sums up the ideas useful to the reader looking to gain market insight; at the end of the book Schwager (the author) looks for similarities between those interviewed. <br /> <br />Beyond a greater understanding of how to make money in the markets, the realization that one doesn't have to be an extremely intuitively gifted buy-and-hold fundamentalist, or a scalper on an exchange floor, etc to make big money and that failure is often inherent with gaining experience (many of those interviewed completely blew out in their early days.) <br /> <br />This is the first of the Wizards series. If you felt that you got a lot from this book (and you probably will,) then I would recommend also reading \\"The New Market Wizards\\" and \\"Stock Market Wizards\\" (the last is better then \\"The New Market Wizards\\" IMO) as well. It should be mentioned that this series of books is very easy to read and quite fun for its genre. <br /> <br />This book is truly worth the 5 stars. Every market participant should read this. Even if you don't trade but cared enough to look at this book's page and check the reviews then you probably should allow yourself to be inspired and enlightened by this book. Do yourself a favor and buy the book.

B000002UC5|5.0|Artist are very sensitive to their environment.  In this, the first of McCartney's solo efforts, he probably felt he had something to prove.  And prove it he did.  IMHO, of all of the post-Beatles albums, only this and \\"All Things Must Pass\\" really reflect the high standards of the formerly Fab Four.  Paul manages to put together a very individualistic piece of work that is, for the most part, quite distinct from the work he did as a Beatle (athough you can hear early versions of a few of the songs on Anthology 3).<br /><br />When the group was together, John and Paul shared songwriting credits and it was always an open question as to how much each individual contributed.  With \\"McCartney\\" Paul showed that he didn't need any help to write a collection of superb songs (some fairly avant-garde).  He also showed his fine musicianship, playing all the instruments himself.  Also, the songs are blessedly free from the silly lyrics that infect much of McCartney's later work - some are free of any lyrics whatsoever.<br /><br />While Paul still managed to create many excellent songs afterwards, unfortunately, as far as albums go, this was the high water mark.  Although this actually was the first LP I ever bought (together with \\"Let It Be\\"), it still sounds fresh many years later.  Now in CD format, it's one of the very few I can play without wanting to first delete out any tracks.<br /><br />While it's a close call, I'd say that \\"Every Night\\" is the best song on this, or any, McCartney album.  For what it's worth, Matthew Sweet does a nice version of it on the tribute album \\"Listen to What the Man Said.\\"

B000850IHW|5.0|I have listened to GG since 1972 but never had the opportunity to see them live. Do have all their albums and since the CD versions of their music started to became available have also acqired many a recording. <br />They broke up in 1979 after 9 years of banging their collective head against the reality their music was only appreciated -and purchased- by a small number of  folks in the continental Europe, part of south America, Thailand and Indonesia. In the Dominican Republic where I am from, we got their music from friends in Puerto Rico (Some times the REAL thing but must of the times just a cassette recording of the album) <br />Have been in the US for the last 25 years and have only found a few souls that ever heard of them. <br />If you enjoyed \\"progressive/orchestral/symphonic\\" music and listened to the likes of YES, GENESIS, ELP, KING CRIMSON, OLD JETHRO TULL, ZAPPA, ECHOLYN, PFM etc, you may like GG......... <br />If you are a music teacher, may want to audition some of their songs. I think some songs are excellent teaching material....... <br />If you already have their recordings and have a decent stereo system you will notice significant sonic improvements over the old versions.......... <br /> <br />Either way, you are buying great/best music, well mastered, cheap and you are financially helping a bunch of guys that truly deserve it. <br />Give them a break. <br />Sincerely <br />Harry Cohen <br /> <br />Please note that early releases of one of the CDs (Interview? The book just throws in a bunch of surprises one would not expect. The only real weakness this story has, is that it was in such complex text, it may be difficult for many to understand. I know for me, I had some troubled at the start of this book because of the language `Alex' created. Over time however, I seemed to adapt to this language, and actually understand it just fine. I recommend this book to those who are capable of reading something in complex text, and would be interested in the frightening ways of how evil sometimes prevails over good.

B000AADYYO|5.0|In only two years since the release of Damnation, Opeth seems to have redefined themselves again. As much as Damnation proved to be a Progressive-Rock influenced, the newest album from the Swede Super Metal band only proves to take experimentation to a new level.    Ghost Reveries seems to tease the listener with a few notes that were felt on Damnation before pelting ears with the trademark growl of the lead vocalist/songwriter Mikael Akerfeldt. The opening song, \\"Ghost of Perdition\\" shows the fans of the heavier sound that Opeth hasn't mellowed out for good and that they still have what it takes to shock and surprise their listeners.    However, just like that last album, they show they are willing to adapt with their music and try new styles and ideas. The addition of Per Wiberg and his expertice of keyboards, pianos and mellotrons adds a perminite change to the Opeth sound. This is very evident if listening carefully to the opening track, but stands out very much so on following tracks. \\"The Baying of the Hounds\\" showcases the new dimension in the opening riff and only shows the new talent added to the band from here on out.    Eastern sounds have even worked their way onto this album, which is evidenced on \\"Atonement\\". You feel as if George Harrison's spirit just walked into the studio when this song was recorded; maybe even a little of John Lennon's too (the drumming is a little reminiscent to \\"Tomorrow Never Knows\\" in opening).    Many times throughout the album you can hear some of Opeth's signature sounds in guitar riffs, bass work and the powerful blast beats layed down by Martin Lopez. But along with this, you can find a more mellow side added in with much thought given to it. The album is for Opeth what Lateralus was to Tool. The simularities are simply uncanning between the two albums. Some of the same guitar work in places, drum beats seem to match and the keyboard work is stellar on both albums.    The weak points to this album are far and few between.One example would be on the song \\"Atonement\\" in which you feel the song has ended, but then three seconds later a new guitar part is added and carries on for another 60 seconds making the song overdone and ruining a terrific oppertunity to lead into the next song perfectly. It just doesn't feel as if it fits. Another weak point would be some transitions where the guys added the duel guitar/keyboard solo that doesn't seem to fit this style of music well.    When sitting down and looking at this album, it is near perfect in every way. Terrific sounds and very insightful ideas outweigh any flaw this album has without a doubt. Like many albums Opeth has released before this one, it is a concept album and a very interesting one at that. Like all the albums released before this one, and surely the ones to follow also, this album will please and surprise all fans and new comers to this wonderfully talented band. Do yourself a favour and pick this up as fast as possible.
